ExampleFolder.title: Server Examples
ExampleFolder.description:
The SmartClient Server framework is a collection of .jar files and optional servlets that work with any J2EE or J2SE container and are easily integrated into existing applications. Its major features include:
  • Simplified server integration: A pre-built network protocol for browser-server communication, which handles data paging, transactions/batch operations, server-side sort, automatic cache updates, validation and other error handling, optimistic concurrency (aka long transactions) and binary file uploads.

  • SQL, JPA & Hibernate Connectors: Secure, flexible, transactional support for all CRUD operations, either directly via JDBC or via Hibernate or JPA beans.

  • Rapid integration with Java Beans: Robust, complete, bi-directional translation between Java and Javascript objects for rapid integration with any Java beans-based persistence system, such as Spring services or custom ORM implementations. Send and receive complex structures including Java Enums and Java Generics without the need to write mapping or validation code. Declaratively trim and rearrange data so that only selected data is sent to the client without the need to create and populate redundant DTOs (data transfer objects).

  • Server enforcement of Validators: A single file specifies validation rules which are enforced on both the client and server side

  • Declarative Security: Easily attach role or capability-based security rules to data operations with server-side enforcement, plus automatic client-side effects such as hiding fields or showing fields as read-only based on the user role.

  • Export: Export any dataset to CSV or true Excel spreadsheets, including data highlights and formatting rules

  • High speed data delivery / data compression: automatically use the fastest possible mechanism for delivering data to the browser
The SmartClient Server framework is an optional, commercially-licensed package. See the products page for details.

ExampleFolder.title: Transactions
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient provides robust support for transactional applications.

Queueing makes combining operations together into a single transaction extremely easy, for more efficient data loading and transactional saves.

Automatic Transaction Management support in the SmartClient Server, with specific implementations for the built-in SQL and Hibernate DataSources, allows for queued requests to be committed or rolled back as a single database transaction. This feature is only available in Power and Enterprise editions.

Transaction Chaining allows for declarative handling of data dependencies between operations submitted together in a queue. This feature is only available in Power and Enterprise editions.

ExampleFolder.title: Component XML
ExampleFolder.description:
Component XML is a format for specifying UI components declaratively in XML.

Using Component XML, you can separate the layout of your application from its business logic, so that less technical users can edit the layout while JavaScript developers implement business logic.

Component XML also allows visual tools such as Visual Builder to be used to modify the layout of your applications.

Example.title: Hello World (xml)
Example.description: This SmartClient DynamicForm provides a text field and a button control. Type a name in the field, then click the button for a personalized message. This example shows embedding JavaScript event handling code directly into Component XML; see the sample "Adding JS Handlers" for keeping event handling and XML layout separate.

Example.title: Adding JS Handlers
Example.description:
The form and button below have been loaded from Component XML, then, a click handler has been added via JavaScript code which performs some specialized validation before saving.

Click the "Save" button to see a warning message generated by the click handler, then check the "In Stock" button and hit "Save" again to allow saving to proceed.

With this development approach, the form and button can be reorganized arbitrarily by editing of XML, possibly in a visual tool such as Visual Builder, or in any tool of your own design that can produce Component XML. So long as the relevant controls and fields are not renamed, the JavaScript code will work unchanged with the new layout.

Example.description:

In the example below, the form and placeholder have been loaded from a Component XML file. Use the "Replace PlaceHolder" button to replace the placeholder with a programatically generated grid component.

Or, check the "Auto-replace Placeholder" checkbox and press the "Reload Component XML" button to see the replacement take place automatically as soon as the Component XML is loaded.

Example.title: Custom Components
Example.description:
You can use custom components in screens created via Component XML. Just use the "constructor" attribute to indicate that your custom class should be used.

You can even provide custom properties to your custom class. In the sample below, the custom ListGrid subclass "MyListGrid" has a boolean setting "hilitePricesOverTen" that causes prices over $10 to appear in red color. This boolean setting is false by default, but the Component XML file sets the property to true on the grid.

It's also possible to declare a Component Schema so that <MyListGrid> can be used directly as the XML tag, with no need to set the constructor or declare the types of custom properties like "hilitePricesOverTen".

Example.title: Screen Reuse
Example.description:
Using createScreen(), you can load multiple copies of the same Component XML screen, and the copies will not interfere with each other. This allows Component XML screens to be treated as simple reusable components.

Use the "DataSources" drop-down below to select a DataSource. Each time you select a new DataSource, a new copy of the same Component XML screen is created, and its components are bound to the selected DataSource.

Example.title: HTTP Proxy
Example.description:
The SmartClient Server includes an HTTP Proxy servlet which supports contacting REST and WSDL web services as though they were hosted by a local web server, avoiding the "same origin policy" restriction which normally prevents web applications from accessing remote services.

The proxy is used automatically whenever an attempt to contact a URL on another host is performed. No special code is needed. In this example, a DataSource is configured to download the Slashdot RSS feed, with no server-side code or proxy configuration required.

Configuration files allow for restricting proxying to specific services that should be accessible to users through your application.

ExampleFolder.title: Mobile Samples
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient provides automatic support for mobile devices:
  • Device-aware layouts adapt to screen size, for example, by switching between side-by-side vs single panel display
  • ComboBoxes, Menus and other components switch to specialized, full-screen interfaces on phone-sized devices
  • Touch-aware components alter interface behavior and component size to be more friendly for touch users
The end result is that enterprise applications built with SmartClient offer are immediately usable on phone and tablet devices with no special effort on the part of the developer.

Example.description:
SplitPane displays up to 3 panes in a device- and orientation-sensitive manner, automatically providing navigation controls between panes for devices that don't have enough room to display panes side-by-side.

This example shows 3 SplitPanes in 3 different tabs, each demonstrating a display and navigation behavior intended for a specific class of device.

If you are using a tablet or handset to view this sample, you can flip it to watch the SplitPane react. Alternatively, use the "Flip" button in each tab, but note that once you have manually set the orientation, the SplitPane will stop responding to device orientation changes.

For devices that use a software keyboard, editing a "phoneNumber" field will bring up a specialized keyboard that only contains digits and other valid phone number characters.

ExampleFolder.title: Adaptive UI
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient components automatically adapt to the smaller screen size and different pointing behavior of mobile devices.

Components like Combo Boxes, Menus and Dialogs will automatically use the entire screen and offer alternative UI for dismissal and navigation (for example: submenus slide in).

Context menus and hovers can be triggered by finger taps or long touches.

Because of these and many other automatic behavior changes for mobile devices, you really can build cross-device applications with a single technology and single codebase.

Example.title: Combo Box
Example.description:
The ComboBoxItem supports a full screen mode to make best use of the limited space available on mobile devices. This mode is automatically enabled for handset / phone-sized devices, but can be enabled for any size device, and is enabled for every kind of device in this sample.

Full screen mode supports all the same features as normal ComboBoxItem - binding to DataSources, data paging, multi-field display and search, etc.

Example.title: Select List
Example.description:
The SelectItem supports a full screen mode to make best use of the limited space available on mobile devices. This mode is automatically enabled for handset / phone-sized devices, but can be enabled for any size device, and is enabled for every kind of device in this sample.

Full screen mode supports all the same features as normal select - binding to DataSources, data paging, multi-field display and search, etc.

Example.title: Menus
Example.description:
Menu components have a special mode for mobile devices. Touch or click the "File" MenuButton below and the Menu will fill the screen with a simplified appearance that omits any rounding or shadows (skin-specific).

Touch the "Recent Documents" menu - the submenu appears using a smooth slide transition, and the navigation bar offers the ability to get back to the main menu or dismiss the entire menu.

These features are automatically enabled for handset / phone-sized devices, but can be enabled for any size device, and is enabled for every kind of device in this sample.

Example.title: Windows & Dialogs
Example.description:
Window & Dialog components have a special mode for mobile devices. Press the "Show" button below and a Window will fill the screen with a simplified appearance that omits any rounding or shadows (skin-specific). These features are automatically enabled for handset / phone-sized devices, but can be enabled for any size device, and is enabled for every kind of device in this sample.

Dismiss the Window and press the "Ask for Value" button - if you are on a mobile phone, the built-in Dialog that asks end users for values behaves the same way.

Example.title: Calendar
Example.description:
For handset-sized devices, the Calendar control has a simplified navigation paradigm: instead of separate tabs for day and week views, you simply pivot the device to switch view. To access the month view, touch the month name.

Note: the described behaviors are only present if accessing this sample from a mobile device.

Example.title: Spinner Control
Example.description:
On touch devices, the SpinnerItem changes appearance and behavior to make it easier to hit the increment and decrement buttons.

In this sample, the appearance normally used only for touch devices is forced on for desktop browsers as well.

Example.title: Adaptive Menu
Example.description:
The AdaptiveMenu component can either display menu items inline, or in a drop-down, or mix the two modes according to available space.

In the example below, a menu is shown inline in a tool strip. Use the resize bar at the right end of the tool strip to reduce the available size, and note how a drop-down control appears that provides access to those items that no longer can be inlined due to the reduced available space. At its minimum width, no items are inlined and access to them all is provided through the drop-down control.

Click the Button that says "Longer Name" and try resizing again. Note how the menu switches to a drop-down sooner, because more space is taken by the name.

This gives users with larger screens instant access to menu options, while still allowing the same functionality to work on smaller screens.

Example.title: Custom Adaptation
Example.description:
SmartClient's adaptive layout system allows components to react to the amount of available space and show a different appearance space for compact spaces.

The example below replicate part of the behavior of the built-in AdaptiveMenu component in order to demonstrate how to write your own adaptive layouts.

In the example below, a menu is shown inline in a tool strip. Use the resize bar at the right end of the tool strip to reduce the available size, and note how a drop-down control appears that provides access to those items that no longer can be inlined due to the reduced available space. At its minimum width, no items are inlined and access to them all is provided through the drop-down control.

Click the Button that says "Longer Name" and try resizing again. Note how the menu switches to a drop-down sooner, because more space is taken by the name.

SmartClient's adaptive layout system allows components to react intelligently to available space, even when the available space depends on dynamic data rather than fixed screen sizes.

ExampleFolder.title: Navigation Bar
ExampleFolder.description: NavigationBar implements the title and navigation behaviors commonly seem in mobile applications, and is a subcomponent used in the mobile rendering of other mobile-aware component such as SplitPane and Menu.

Example.title: Title Auto-Fit
Example.description:
The NavigationBar component features intelligent auto-fitting behavior for the title area, designed to make best use of space for titles that may based on dynamic data, such as a property of the selected record in a grid.

Press the buttons below the NavigationBar to see the behaviors with different titles:

  • the title "Fa Bai" fits neatly and is centered
  • the title "Abe Jacobs" is slightly too long to fit with the navigation buttons, so it is intentionally placed slightly off-center, up to a configurable maximum off-center distance
  • for a longer title like "Izabella Chernyak F.", the title of the left navigation button is hidden (leaving just the left-pointing arrow)
  • finally, for a very long title like "Christine Bergeron Fewell", the title is clipped and an ellipsis shown
Note that while auto-fitting works regardless of the skin or browser used, the specific titles chosen for this sample may be slightly shorter or longer in different skins or on computers will less fonts installed, and so may trigger the auto-fitting behaviors described above differently.

Example.title: Animated Transitions
Example.description:
The NavigationBar component has subtle, built-in animations to help users keep their sense of place.

Press "New" to do a right transition - notice how the old title slides left and fades while the changed buttons fade in place.

Press "Back" for a left transition - notice how the title from the left button appears to slide over to become the title, as the old title fades out.

Example.title: Offline support
Example.description:
SmartClient has support for caching server responses in browser storage, allowing these cached responses to be returned to an application at some future point when the application is offline. Offline support is automatic once enabled - if the user switches the application or browser into offline mode, or the browser detects that it is offline, the framework automatically and transparently starts returning cached responses whenever it can (application code can determine that responses have come from offline cache if necessary)

Use the tree to navigate categories. Click a category to load the grid with matching items. Now reload the page and click "Go offline" (or switch the browser into offline mode). If a category is clicked that had previously been selected before the reload, the grid will still be populated from the Offline cache. If a category is clicked that had not been previously selected, or a node is opened in the tree that had not been previously opened, the "Data not available while offline" message will be displayed.

Example.title: Offline preferences
Example.description:
SmartClient provides a unified Offline browser storage API that can be used for any client-side persistence task. In this example, the ListGrid's viewState to browser-local storage is stored. Try resizing or reordering some columns in the grid, click "Persist State", then press F5 to reload, or close and re-open the browser. The changes have been remembered. Try adding a formula field to the grid and reload again. Persisting a user's preferences like this is a compelling addition to any application, and in this case doesn't even require a server round trip.

Offline support is provided in modern HTML5 browsers, and also in older versions of Internet Explorer (6 and greater). The underlying technologies used are very different, but the SmartClient API is the same, regardless of which browser is used.

When the dataset becomes small enough, SmartClient switches to client-side filtering automatically. Enter more letters, or criteria on other columns, to see this. The label underneath the grid flashes briefly every time SmartClient needs to visit the server.

Delete part of the item name to see SmartClient automatically switch back to server-side filtering when necessary.

Adaptive filtering eliminates up to 90% of the most costly types of server contact (searching through large datasets), dramatically improving responsiveness and scalability.

Example.description:
By default, a ListGrid with showFilterEditor set to true will generate criteria with a default search operator, according to the grid's textMatchStyle. However, if allowFilterOperators is also set to true, users are permitted to alter the search operator for any ListGrid field, if its filterEditor field is based on regular text input, rather than a picker of some sort.

This example shows a grid with allowFilterOperators set to true and pre-specified criteria that applies non-standard search operators to two fields - Country Name must not contain any 'i' characters and Capital must not begin with a 'p'. You can see that those two fields display an operatorIcon that shows the symbol for the corresponding search expression. You can change the search operator either by clicking this icon, if it's visible (otherwise by right-clicking in the field), or by using the headerContextMenu to show the "Filter using" menu.

Try adding a third filter value - right-click the Area field in the filterEditor and select "greater than" from the "Filter using" menu. Now, enter 1001450 into the search field and press enter. Click the icon again, select "less than" and press enter again to enforce the opposite filter. Click the icon again and select the first entry, labelled equals (default) - this reverts the field to using its default search operator, and hides the operatorIcon.

Example.title: Advanced Filter
Example.description: SmartClient's Advanced Filter feature allows you to create complex, multi-condition filters. Ordinary DynamicForms can be used to generate AdvancedCriteria objects, as is shown here, simply by specifying a valid "operator" on one or more of the form fields.

Example.title: Custom Filter
Example.description: Use the FilterBuilder to construct custom queries that combine multiple criteria across any field in your DataSource. Note that the operator select list only shows operators suitable for the field selected, and the comparison field changes to suit the type of the selected field (for example, select field "independence" and note that the comparison field changes to a date). Add clauses to your query with the "+" icon. Click "Filter" to see the result in the ListGrid.

Example.title: Nested Filter
Example.description:
Use the FilterBuilder to construct queries of arbitrary complexity. The FilterBuilder, and the underlying AdvancedCriteria system, support building queries with subclauses nested to any depth. The initial criteria in this example is set up to display only European countries where either the name ends with "land", or the population is less than 3 million - an unlikely query, perhaps, but one that shows the simplest example of the FilterBuilder's flexibility.

Add clauses to the query with the "+" icon. Add nested subclauses with the "+()" button. Click "Filter" to see the result in the ListGrid.

Example.title: Big Filter
Example.description:
When a FilterBuilder must work with a very large number of fields, it is possible to set FilterBuilder.fieldDataSource to a DataSource containing records that represent the fields to display in the FieldPickers in each clause. The FilterBuilder below is created without a normal DataSource, but specifies a fieldDataSource and the FieldPicker items in each clause are populated dynamically with it's records. In this mode, the FieldPickers are represented by ComboBoxItems, rather than SelectItems, and have default settings that provide type-ahead auto-completion.

Note also that, when fieldDataSource is specified and the operator for a clause is of a type that uses a field-lookup, the valueField is also populated dynamically by the fieldDataSource.

Example.title: Disable filter
Example.description: Type "island" above the "Country" column, then press Enter or click the filter button (top-right corner of the grid) to show only countries with "island" in their name. Select "North America" above the "Continent" column to filter countries by that continent. Filtering is disabled on the "Flag" and "Capital" columns.

Example.title: Date Range
Example.description:
Smartclient provides special widgets for filtering date values, including recognised RelativeDate strings that cause filtering relative to some other base date.

The RelativeDateRangeItem allows selection of dates in three ways: you can select a preset date string, like "Today" or "Tomorrow", or a "ranged" date string, such as "N days from now" and enter a quantity to associate with it, or you can directly enter a date string in a recognized format. You can also select a date from the DateChooser by clicking the icon to the right of the widget.

The first example below demonstrates using a DateRangeItem in a seperate DynamicForm to filter a ListGrid. Select start and end values for the range using one of the methods described above and click the "Search" button to see the data filtered according to the values in the "Nationhood" field.

The second example below demonstrates filtering grid data using a MiniDateRangeItem to filter data when a ListGrid is showing it's FilterEditor. In this example, click the Date icon in the header for the "Nationhood" field to open a popup DateRangeItemDialog. In the dialog, select start and end values for the range, as described above, and click Ok to close the Window. Then click the Filter button in the top right of the grid to see the data filtered. You can hover the mouse over the "Nationhood" field-header to see the full date-range string.

Example.title: Date Range (Presets)
Example.description:
SmartClient provides a PresetCriteriaItem, which allows a user to select criteria from a SelectItem using a recognizable display-name, from a list of options provided to it. The item can also include a "Custom..." entry which, when selected, calls the getCustomCriteria() override point, allowing the developer to provide a custom interface for selecting criteria. There's also a simple subclass of this item, PresetDateRangeItem, which has custom code to show a DateRangeDialog for collecting custom-criteria.

This example demonstrates using a subclass of the second example in both a ListGrid's FilterEditor, and in a stand-alone FilterBuilder.A simple subclass of PresetDateRangeItem is created, called RecentDateRangeItem, that lists a number of common options for filtering by recent date ranges. This is then used as an editor in both UIs. In the first example, select an option in the "Order Date" field and click the 'Filter' icon to see the filter applied. In the second example, choose a named-range in the "value" field to the right of the FilterBuilder and click the 'Filter' button below to have the selected criteria applied to the bottom grid.

Example.title: Expression filter
Example.description:
DynamicForms and FormItems are capable of parsing simple expressions entered as part of their values, when allowExpressions is true on either entity. ListGrids use this facility, when showFilterEditor and allowFilterExpressions are true, to allow expressions to be entered directly into the FormItems displayed in the filterEditor.

Below is a ListGrid with a FilterEditor and allowFilterExpressions: true. Some expression-based filter-criteria has been applied via initialCriteria. The list displays countries with no 'i's in the country name, with a "Capital" that starts with a letter "A" through "F" and with a "Population" less than 1 million or more than 100 million.

See the table on the right for the supported expression-symbols. Note that logical "and" and "or" expressions are treated as text in text-based fields and ignored.

ExampleFolder.title: Sorting
ExampleFolder.description: SmartClient grids provide interactive sorting of standard and custom data types, with automatic client/server coordination.

Example.title: Sort
Example.description: Click on any column header to sort by that column. To reverse the sort direction, click on the same column header, or the top-right corner of the grid.

Example.title: Disable sort
Example.description: Sorting is disabled on the "Flag" column. Click on any other column header to sort on the corresponding column.

Example.title: Sort arrows
Example.description: Click on any column header to sort or reverse-sort by that column. This grid shows the sort-direction arrow in the top-right corner only.

Example.title: Data-Aware Sort
Example.description: Click on any column header to sort by that column. The "Nationhood", "Area", and "GDP (per capita)" columns are sorted as date, number, and calculated number values, respectively.

Example.title: Multilevel Sort (UI)
Example.description:
This grid is displayed pre-sorted on two fields: first by "Category" ascending and then by "Item Name" descending. As well as the field's title, the header of each field included in the sort configuration displays a sort-arrow indicating the direction of sort on that field and, when multiple fields are sorted, a small numeral indicating this field's position in the list of fields being sorted. By using SHIFT-click, an already sorted column-headers direction can be reversed, or an unsorted column header can be added to the list of fields being sorted. Clicking a column header without holding down SHIFT clears the current sort configuration and initializes a new sort on the selected field.

SmartClient's SQL and Hibernate adapters support server-side multi-sorting and this is in evidence in this example.

Example.title: Multilevel Sort (Dialog)
Example.description: Click the "Multilevel Sort" button to show a MultiSortDialog. Select a set of sort properties and directions and click "Save" to see the grid re-sorted by those properties.

Example.title: Adaptive Sort
Example.description: SmartClient combines large dataset handling with adaptive use of client-side sort. Click any header and server-side sort will be used for this large dataset. Check "Limit to Dictonarics" to limit the dataset and sort again. When the dataset becomes small enough, SmartClient switches to client-side sorting automatically. The label underneath the grid flashes briefly every time SmartClient needs to visit the server.

ExampleFolder.title: Editing
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient grids provide inline editing of all data types, with automatic validation and client/server updates.

These examples are all bound to the same remote DataSource, so the changes are saved on SmartClient.com and will appear in all Grid Editing examples during this session. To end the SmartClient.com session and reset the example data on the server, simply close all instances of the web browser.

Example.title: Edit by row
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing. Use Tab, Shift-Tab, Up Arrow and Down Arrow to move between cells. Changes are saved automatically when moving to another row. Press Enter to save the current row and dismiss the editors, or Esc to discard changes for the current row and dismiss the editors.

Example.title: Edit by cell
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing. Use Tab, Shift-Tab, Up Arrow and Down Arrow to move between cells. Press Enter to save the current row and dismiss the editors, or Esc to discard changes for the current cell and dismiss the editors.

Example.title: Custom Cell Editors
Example.description: Click on any cell of the "Value Field" column to start editing. This example illustrates have cell editors can be customized for the same ListGridField, but different records using ListGrid.getEditorProperties(..)

Example.title: Enter new rows
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing, then Tab or Down Arrow past the last row in the grid to create a new row. Alternatively, click the "Edit New" button to create a new data-entry row at the end of the grid.

Example.title: Mass Update
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing, then Tab or Down Arrow past the last row in the grid to create a new row. Alternatively, click the "Edit New" button to create a new data-entry row at the end of the grid. Unlike the other editing examples, none of the changes are being automatically saved to the server. Note how SmartClient highlights changed values, and new rows. Click the "Save" button to save all changes at once, or click the "Discard" button to discard all changes (including any new rows) and revert to the data as it was before editing started.

Example.title: Modal editing
Example.description: Double-click on any cell to start editing. Click anywhere outside of the cell editors to save changes, or press the Esc key to discard changes.

Example.title: Disable editing
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing. Use Tab/Arrow keys to move between cells, Enter/Esc keys to save or cancel. Editing is disabled for the "Country" and "G8" columns.

Example.title: Custom editors
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing. The "Government", "Population", and "Nationhood" columns specify custom editors. In this example, they are a multiple-line Text Area, a Numeric Spinner and a Compound Date Control.

Example.title: Data validation
Example.description: Click on any cell to start editing. Delete the value in a "Country" cell, or type a non-numeric value in a "Population" cell, to see validation errors.

Example.title: Dependent Selects
Example.description:
In the first example, Double Click on any row to start editing. Select a value in the "Division" column to change the set of options available in the "Department" column.

In the second example, click the "Order New Item" button to add an editable row to the grid. Select a "Category" in the second column to change the set of options available in the "Item" column.

Example.title: Editor Formula
Example.description: This example demonstrates a grid editorFormula field. Select an item and edit the cost to see price calculated from cost and separate markup percent. Price can also be entered to override calculation. Note that cost is not saved.

ExampleFolder.title: Frozen Columns
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient supports rendering out grids with frozen fields.

Frozen fields are fields that do not scroll horizontally with the other fields, remaining visible on the screen while other fields may be scrolled out of view.

Example.title: Simple Freeze
Example.description: Setting frozen:true on a column definition establishes a frozen column. Column resize and reorder work normally.

Example.title: Dynamic Freeze
Example.description:
Right click on any column header to show a menu that allows you to freeze that column. Multiple columns may be frozen, and frozen columns may be reordered.
Right click on a frozen column to unfreeze it.

Example.title: Editing
Example.description: SmartClient's inline editing support works normally with frozen columns with no further configuration.

Example.title: Drag and Drop
Example.description: SmartClient's drag and drop support works normally with frozen columns with no further configuration. Drag countries within grids to reorder them, or between grids to move countries back and forth.

ExampleFolder.title: Grouping & Summaries
ExampleFolder.description: List entries can be grouped according to field value.

Example.title: Dynamic Grouping
Example.description: Right click on any column header to show a menu that allows grouping by that column. Right click and select "Ungroup" to return to a flat listing.

Example.title: Grouped Editing
Example.description: Inline editing works normally with grouped data. Edit the field that records are grouped by and notice that the record will move to its new group automatically.

Example.title: Custom Grouping
Example.description: You can specify custom grouping behaviors for a field. Group by the "Nationhood" and "Population" fields to see examples of custom grouping.

Example.title: Multi Grouping
Example.description:
Grids support multiple levels of grouping, including a built-in dialog that allows users to configure grouping. This is enabled by a single setting: canMultiGroup.

The grid below is grouped by Category, then by Ship Date. Push the "Configure Grouping" button to launch a dialog for configuring multi-level grouping. This can also be accessed from the drop-down menu on any column header, via the "Configure Grouping..." menu item.

Example.title: Grouping Modes
Example.description: This sample shows that a single ListGrid field may be grouped in more than one way, by setting its groupingModes property, a valueMap. By default the grid is shown grouped by the "Hemisphere" mode of the Continent field--you can also group by the Continent Name. Similarly, there are two ways to group by the Nationhood field. You must define the getGroupValue() method of a field to apply logic appropriate to the field's groupingMode.

Example.title: Grid Summaries
Example.description:
ListGrids support displaying summaries of the current data set in various ways. Fields from individual records can be summarized into a single field value. In this example the "Total" field displays a summary value calculated by multiplying the "Quantity" and "Price" fields.

Summaries can also be displayed for multiple records. This example shows a summary row at the end of each group in the grid, as well as an overall summary row with information about every record in the grid. Note that in addition to standard summary functions such as "sum" to generate a total, or "count" to generate a count of records, completely custom functions may be used. This is demonstrated in the "Category" field where a custom function determines how many categories exist in this dataset.

Click to edit and summaries are dynamically re-calculated to reflect the changes made.

Example.title: Grid Header Summary
Example.description:
ListGrids support displaying summaries of the current data set in various ways. Fields from individual records can be summarized into a single field value. In this example the "Total" field displays a summary value calculated by multiplying the "Quantity" and "Price" fields.

Summaries can also be displayed for multiple records. This example shows a summary row at the end of each group in the grid as well as an overall summary row with information about every record in the grid. Note that in addition to standard summary functions such as "sum" to generate a total, or "count" to generate a count of records, completely custom functions may be used. This is demonstrated in the "Category" field where a custom function determines how many categories exist in this dataset.

As illustrated in this sample, by calling showGroupSummaryInHeader:true field summary values for each group are displayed directly in the group header node, rather than showing up at the bottom of each expanded group.

Example.title: Multi Line Summaries
Example.description:
ListGrids support displaying summaries of the current data set in various ways. Fields from individual records can be summarized into a single field value. In this example the "Total" field displays a summary value calculated by multiplying the "Quantity" and "Price" fields.

Summaries can also be displayed for multiple records. This example shows a summary row at the end of each group in the grid as well as an overall summary row with information about every record in the grid. Note that in addition to standard summary functions such as "sum" to generate a total, or "count" to generate a count of records, completely custom functions may be used. This is demonstrated in the "Category" field where a custom function determines how many categories exist in this dataset.

By calling summaryFunction multiple times allows for applying more than one summary function to a field. This allows the developer to set up multi-line summaries where each specified summary function result will show up in a separate summary row.

ExampleFolder.title: Expanding Rows
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient grids support a special expansionField.

When grid.canExpandRecords is true, the expansionField is rendered out at the beginning of the field list. When this field is clicked for a record, the record is expanded and a built-in component is embedded into the record's row, beneath it's field values.

A variety of components are supported by default, according to the value grid.expansionMode, and grid.getExpansionComponent() can also be overriden to add custom expansion behaviors.

Example.title: Detail Field
Example.description: This grid displays fields from the Countries DataSource. Expand a row by clicking the special expansionField to see the details of the selected country's background in the expanded section.

Example.title: Details
Example.description: This grid displays a limited number of fields from the supplyItem DataSource. Expand a row by clicking the special expansionField to see a DetailViewer embedded in the expanded portion of the record which displays the rest of the data from the DataSource that isn't already visible in the grid.

Example.title: Related Records
Example.description: In this grid of Supply Categories, expand a row by clicking the special expansionField to see a sub-grid containing the list of Supply Items applicable to the selected "Category".

Example.title: Custom Component
Example.description:
This sample uses a Custom Expansion Component to achieve what the Related Records sample does with built-in SmartClient Framework functionality.

In this grid of Supply Categories, expand a row by clicking the special expansionField to see a sub-grid containing the list of Supply Items applicable to the selected "Category".

Example.title: Limited Data
Example.description:
This grid displays a limited number of fields from the supplyItem DataSource. Only the visible data values have been returned from the server, via the operationBinding.outputs feature. Expand a row by clicking the special expansionField. The system will access the server to retrieve the entire record, create a DetailViewer to display that data and expand the row to show the DetailViewer. See the code in the overridden getExpansionComponent() method.

Note also the use of the maxExpandedRecords attribute to limit the total number of simultaneously expanded records.

ExampleFolder.title: Hiliting
ExampleFolder.description:
The "hiliting" system allows end users to visually define data highlighting rules, such as using colors to pick out high values, or using multiple colors to indicate ranges of values.

Because "hilites" can be easily stored and re-applied, it's easy to build an interface that allows users to store their own private data highlighting rules, or even build a highlighted report to share with other users.

Example.title: User Defined
Example.description:
DataBoundComponents allow end-users to create "hilites" with rules based on the values of data. There are two sorts of hilites. Simple hilites, which allow a single criterion based on a single field to affect a single target field (the same one) and Advanced hilites, which allow very complex criteria, based on multiple fields, to affect multiple target fields.

Click the "Edit Hilites" button below to show the HiliteEditor interface. To set up a simple hilite, click on the "Area (km2)" record in the list to the left. When the simple hilite rule appears on the right, select the "greater than" operation from the drop-down box, type "5000000" into the value textBox, select a color from the Color picker widget and click "Save". Notice that all "Area (km2)" values in the grid that exceed 5000000 are now highlighted in the chosen color.

Now, add an Advanced criteria. Again, click the "Edit Hilites" button and then click the "Add Advanced Rule" button in the top left of the HiliteEditor - The AdvancedHiliteEditor window is displayed. Add a new criterion that specifies "GDP ($M) greater than 1000000". Click the green plus icon beneath the criterion and add a second criterion, this time specifying "Area (km2) less than 500000". In the list below, select both "GDP ($M)" and "Area (km2)" and select a background color. Clicking "Save" now will update the grid, showing both "GDP" and "Area" data in your selected background color, where "GDP" is higher than 1 million and "Area" is less than 500,000.

It is very easy to provide users with the ability to save and restore their hilite information by simply having the ability to save the data as a string. Click the button below to see the grid's hilite state retrieved and serialized, by calling getHiliteState(), the grid destroyed and it's hilite-state restored to another grid via setHiliteState().

Example.title: Pre-Defined
Example.description:
This example demonstrates producing hilites in code. The hilites applied to the grid below match those suggested in the User Defined hilites example. Additionaly, the Advanced Hilite in this example also demonstrates using Canvas.imgHTML() and the htmlAfter attribute of hilite-objects to append a warning icon to the end of each field value, as part of the hilite.

Hilite-objects also support an htmlBefore attribute - These before and after properties can be used to extend color-based hilites to format values, for instance, as bold or italic text using HTML tags.

Example.title: Data-Driven
Example.description: This example demonstrates hiliting in a data-driven fashion, where hilites contain no criteria, and instead the data itself is flagged by setting the DataBoundComponent.hiliteProperty attribute on each record. This method is useful when complex server-based calculation is used to decide which records to hilite, and the client only needs to handle displaying them.

Example.title: Formula Hilites
Example.description:
Hiliting can be applied to any field in a DataBoundComponent, including custom formula and summary fields.

Launch the Formula Builder and enter the title of the new field, and the desired formula. In this case, enter "Population Density" for the field title and in the formula field enter "A / B". As indicated in the dialog, "A" represents the "Population" field, and "B" represents the "Area" field. Notice that sorting is now available on this newly added "Population Density" field, just like any other field. Click the help icon to view the various supported built-in functions.

Now, click the "Edit Hilites" button to show the HiliteEditor interface. To set up a simple hilite on the custom "Population Density" field, select it in the list to the left. When the simple hilite rule appears on the right, select the "greater than" operation from the drop-down box, type "300" into the value textBox, select a color from the Color picker widget and click "Save". You'll see that all the grid-values in the "Population Density" field that exceed 300 are now hilighted in the chosen color.

ExampleFolder.title: Cell Widgets
ExampleFolder.description: Examples of SmartClient's ability to embed arbitrary widgets in ListGrid cells.

Example.title: Grid Cell Widgets
Example.description: This example illustrates embedding arbitrary widgets in ListGrid cells. Notice how reordering the column with widgets works as any other column. SmartClient uses widget pooling to maximize efficiency.

Example.title: Grid Record Widgets
Example.description: This example illustrates embedding a row level widget in a ListGrid Record. SmartClient uses widget pooling to maximize efficiency.

ExampleFolder.title: Hover Components
ExampleFolder.description:
Any SmartClient Canvas can display a hover label when a user pauses momentarily above it. This is a built-in behavior for showing arbitrary HTML text, configured by returning a value from Canvas.hoverHTML. In addition to this, the built-in Hover Label can be replaced with any other Canvas-based component by overriding and returning a component from getHoverComponent().

This section covers some examples of this feature.

When showHoverComponents is true and the mouse hovers over a field, a built-in component is created and used in place of the standard hover Label.

A variety of components are supported by default, according to the value of grid.hoverMode, and overriding grid.getHoverComponent() allows for adding custom hover behaviors.

Example.title: Related Records
Example.description:
In this grid of Customer Orders, hover over a row to see a list of messages attached to the order. This gives a quick preview of discussions about the order, without the need to leave the list of orders.

In a complete application, clicking the order would lead to a detail screen showing the full order details and the ability to add to the discussion.

Example.title: Custom Components
Example.description: This grid displays a limited number of fields from the supplyItem DataSource. Only the visible data values been returned from the server, via the operationBinding.outputs feature. When hovering over a row, the system returns to the server to retrieve the entire record, creates a DetailViewer to display that data and shows it as the hoverComponent. See the code in the overridden getCellHoverComponent() method.

Example.title: Custom Columns
Example.description:
Formula and Summary fields provide built-in wizards for end users to define formula fields that can compute values using other fields, or summary fields that can combine other fields with intervening / surrounding text. Available in all DataBoundComponents and easy to persist as preferences.

The Formula and Summary Builders are accessible from the grid header context menu. They can also be invoked programmatically as demonstrated by clicking the buttons in this sample.

Launch the Formula Builder and enter the title of the new field, and the desired formula. For example, enter "Population Density" for the field title and in the formula field enter "A / B". As indicated in the dialog, A represents the "Population" field, and B represents the "Area" field. Notice sorting is now available on this newly added "Population Density" field just like any other field. Click the help icon to view the various supported built-in functions.

Next, launch the Summary Builder and enter the title of the new field, and the Summary formulation. For example, enter "Country (Flag)" for the field name and enter "#B (#A)" in the summary field.

Once some additional user-fields have been added, all that is needed to persist the column-layout for later restoration to another grid, is the ability to save a string. Click the button below to store the grid's state by calling getFieldState(), destroy the grid and restore it's state to another grid using setFieldState().

ExampleFolder.title: Tiling
ExampleFolder.description: Using the TileGrid to display data in a tiled format.

Example.title: Basic
Example.description: SmartClient can display data in a "tiled" view. Mouse over widgets to see rollovers, click to select (shift- and ctrl-click for multi-select).

Example.title: Filter & Sort
Example.description: Tiled views can be filtered and sorted just like ListGrids. Use the "Search" form to eliminate some tiles and watch remaining tiles animate to new positions. Use the "Sort" form to change the sort direction.

Example.title: Editing
Example.description: Tiled views can be connected to editors. The TiledView automatically reacts to changes to the underlying dataset. Change the life span of Gazelle to 2 to see it animate to the beginning of the list.

Example.title: Customized Tiles
Example.description: The tiles in a TileGrid can be customized. This example demonstrates adding a "Remove" button to each tile which, when clicked, executes a DataSource operation to remove the selected tile.

Example.title: Fully Custom Tiles
Example.description:
TileGrids allow a completely custom component to be used as the tile.

In this sample, each tile is a DynamicForm (with no editable fields). The tabular layout of the DynamicForm has been used to show each animals' status (Endangered) and lifespan adjacent to its image, instead of beneath it.

Example.title: Export
Example.description:
It's now easy to export data from a DataSource or from DataboundComponents, such as ListGrid, TreeGrid and TileGrid. In the example below, choose an export format from the "Export Type" list, decide whether to download the results or view them in a window using the checkbox and click the "Export" button. Because exporting to JSON is allowed only via server-side custom code or via an OperationBinding (for security reasons), choosing JSON from the select-item issues the export using the operationId set up in the DataSource but still respects the "Show in Window" checkbox. See the "JS" and "worldDSExport" tabs below.

Try changing the filters and sort-order on the grid to see that the exported data is filtered and sorted according to criteria applied to the grid.

Example.title: Preferences
Example.description:
This example illustrates how a ListGrid configuration can be saved as a user preference and later restored. Notice how the position of custom fields created by the Formula Builder and Summary Builder are also captured and restored.
The ListGrid configuration comprises of field state, sort state and selection state and these can be obtained separately by calling ListGrid.getFieldState(), ListGrid.getSortState() and ListGrid.getSelectedState() respectively. ListGrid.getViewState() can be called to return all three states.
The configuration state is a String which can be sent to the server to store and later retrieve the ListGrid state.

ExampleFolder.title: Data types
ExampleFolder.description: Built-in display and editing behaviors for common data types, and how to customize them.

Example.title: Text
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. All fields in this grid are text fields.

Example.title: Image
Example.description: "Flag" is an image field.

Example.title: Long Text
Example.description: Click on the data values to edit. "Government" is a long text field with a popup editor.

Example.title: Date
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "Nationhood" is a date field.

Example.title: Integer
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "Population" is an integer field.

Example.title: Decimal
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "GDP" is a decimal (aka float) field.

Example.title: Boolean
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "G8" is a boolean (true/false) field.

Example.title: Link (text)
Example.description: Click on the values in the "Info" column to open external links.

Example.title: Link (image)
Example.description: Click on the book images in the "Info" column to open external links.

Example.title: List
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "Continent" is a list (aka valueMapped) field.

Example.title: Calculated
Example.description: Click on the column headers to sort, or on the data values to edit. "GDP (per capita)" is calculated from the "GDP" and "Population" fields.

ExampleFolder.title: Data binding
ExampleFolder.description: How to bind grids to DataSources to share field (column) definitions with other components, and how to load data from local and remote data sources and services.

Example.title: ListGrid fields
Example.description: This ListGrid takes its field (column) settings from the fields property of the component definition only. This technique is appropriate for presentation-only grids that do not require data binding.

Example.title: DataSource fields

High-performance interactive tree views

Trees are based on grid views, and so share all of the appearance, interactivity and databinding features of grids, in addition to tree-specific features.

ExampleFolder.title: Appearance
ExampleFolder.description: Trees can have dynamic titles, display multiple columns and show connector lines.

Example.title: Node Titles
Example.description: Formatter interfaces allow you to add custom tree titles.

Example.title: Multiple Columns
Example.description:
Trees can show multiple columns of data for each node. Each column has the styling, formatting, and data type awareness features of columns in a normal grid.
Try drag reordering columns, or sorting by the "Salary" field.

Example.title: Connectors
Example.description: Trees can show skinnable connector lines. Toggle the checkbox to show or hide "full" connector lines.

ExampleFolder.title: Dragging
ExampleFolder.description: Trees have built-in drag and drop behaviors and tree-specific events.

Example.title: Drag reparent
Example.description: Try dragging employees under new managers. Note that a position indicator line appears during drag, allowing employees to be placed in a particular order.

Example.title: Springloaded Folders
Example.description: Try dragging employees under new managers. Note that closed folders automatically open if you hover over them momentarily.

Example.title: Drop Events
Example.description: Click on any category on the left to show items from that category on the right. Drag and drop items from the list on the right into new categories in the tree on the left.

Example.title: Cascading Selection
Example.description: Tree selection can be automatically propagated up and down the tree. Select a parent or child node to see how other nodes are affected.

ExampleFolder.title: Data binding
ExampleFolder.description: Trees can bind to DataSources and handle all the data formats that grids can, using additional properties to control tree structure, open state, and folders.

Example.description: Tree data can be specified as a flat list of nodes that refer to each other by ID. This format is also used for load on demand.

Example.title: Children Arrays
Example.description: Tree data can be specified as a tree of nodes where each node lists its children.

Example.description: Tree data can be loaded in XML or JSON format. For a "children arrays" Tree, one DataSource field is marked childrenProperty:true, and the children of a node are expected to appear under the same-named XML element or JSON property.

Example.title: Load on Demand
Example.description: Begin opening folders and note the prompt which briefly appears during server fetches. Trees can load data one folder at a time. When a folder is opened for the first time, the tree asks the server for the children of the node just opened by passing the unique id of the parent as search criteria.

Example.description:
Begin opening folders and note the load on demand behavior.
Trees that use load on demand can optional specify an initial dataset set up front.

Example.description:
Server logic can return multiple levels of the tree in response to a single request when using load on demand.

In the tree below, the nodes "Charles Madigen" and "Tammy Plant" have been returned by the server already open. The server included the children of these nodes to avoid the need for the tree to immediately contact the server again to load children.

Example.description:
Server logic can return multiple levels of the tree in response to a single request when using child paging.

In the tree below, the folders "Root #4" and "First #5" have been returned by the server already open. The server included the children of these nodes to avoid the need for the tree to immediately contact the server again to load children.

However, both of these nodes have a very large number of children, so they only returned a portion of their children, using the childCountProperty to tell the tree the total number of children.

Example.title: Filtering
Example.description:
Trees can be filtered without server-side support. Parent nodes can be dropped if they don't match the criteria or they can be retained if matching children are present. Click on the "filter" buttons to change the filter criteria.
Note that if "keep parents" is not checked, keepParentsOnFilter will be false for the TreeGrid in the sample, excluding all nodes not matching the criteria, and all nodes below the excluded nodes in the TreeGrid. (So if the filter excludes the root node, no nodes will be visible.)

Changes made in the tree or ListGrid are automatically saved to the server and reflected in the other components.

Setting frozen:true enables frozen columns for Trees. Columns can be frozen and unfrozen by right-clicking on column headers.
Column resize, column reorder, drag and drop and load on demand all function normally. Double click a cell to edit.

Example.title: Text - Masked
Example.description:
TextItems support a masked entry system to restrict and format data entry.

Overview of available mask characters

Character Description
0 Digit (0 through 9) or plus [+] or minus [-] signs
9 Digit or space
# Digit
L Letter (A through Z)
? Letter (A through Z) or space
A Letter or digit
a Letter or digit
C Any character or space
 
< Causes all characters that follow to be converted to lowercase
> Causes all characters that follow to be converted to uppercase

Any character not matching one of the above mask characters or that is escaped with a backslash (\) is considered to be a literal.

Custom mask characters can be defined by a standard regular expression character set or range. For example, a hexadecimal color code mask could be:

  • Color: \#>[0-9A-F][0-9A-F][0-9A-F][0-9A-F][0-9A-F][0-9A-F]

ExampleFolder.title: Server examples
ExampleFolder.description:
The SmartClient Server framework is a collection of .jar files and optional servlets that work with any J2EE or J2SE container and are easily integrated into existing applications. Its major features include:
  • Simplified server integration: A pre-built network protocol for browser-server communication, which handles data paging, transactions/batch operations, server-side sort, automatic cache updates, validation and other error handling, optimistic concurrency (aka long transactions) and binary file uploads.

  • SQL, JPA & Hibernate Connectors: Secure, flexible, transactional support for all CRUD operations, either directly via JDBC or via Hibernate or JPA beans.

  • Rapid integration with Java Beans: Robust, complete, bi-directional translation between Java and Javascript objects for rapid integration with any Java beans-based persistence system, such as Spring services or custom ORM implementations. Send and receive complex structures including Java Enums and Java Generics without the need to write mapping or validation code. Declaratively trim and rearrange data so that only selected data is sent to the client without the need to create and populate redundant DTOs (data transfer objects).

  • Server enforcement of Validators: A single file specifies validation rules which are enforced on both the client and server side

  • Declarative Security: Easily attach role or capability-based security rules to data operations with server-side enforcement, plus automatic client-side effects such as hiding fields or showing fields as read-only based on the user role.

  • Export: Export any dataset to CSV or true Excel spreadsheets, including data highlights and formatting rules

  • High speed data delivery / data compression: automatically use the fastest possible mechanism for delivering data to the browser
The SmartClient Server framework is an optional, commercially-licensed package. See the products page for details.

It is important to note that this can be done, whilst still keeping the normal benefits of SmartClient DataSources, such as automatic dataset paging and arbitrary filtering and sorting. Also note that this example, though it makes heavy use of custom SQL clauses, doesn't make use of any database-specific syntax or functions, so it is portable across different database products.

The list contains a summary of orders in a given date range, summarized by item - each item appears just once in the list, alongside the total quantity of that item ordered in the given date range. Change the date range to be more restrictive (all the rows in the sample database have dates in February 2009) and click "Filter", Note how the quantities change, and items disappear from the list. Also, use the filter editor at the top of the grid to arbitrarily filter the records, or click the column headings to sort.

Scroll the grid quickly to the bottom, and a brief notification will be seen, as SmartClient contacts the server. Pagination still works normally, despite the unusual and complex query.

ExampleFolder.description: The SmartClient Server's built-in support for Hibernate

Example.title: HB Auto Derivation
Example.description:
If you have pre-existing Hibernate beans, SmartClient can automatically derive fully functional DataSources given just the Java classname of the Hibernate Bean. The grid below is connected to a Hibernate-managed bean via the simple declarations in supplyItemHBAutoDerive.ds.xml - no other configuration or Java code is required beyond the bean itself and possibly Hibernate mappings (.hbm.xml files). In this sample, the bean is annotated, so no separate mappings are required.

To search, use the controls above the grid's header. Note that data paging is automatically enabled. Scroll down to load data on demand. Click on the red icon next to each record to delete it. Click on a record to edit it and click "Add New" to add a new record. Note that the editing controls are type sensitive. A date picker appears for the "Next Shipment" field, and the "Units" field shows a picklist as its Java type is an Enum. Also note that the "Item Name" and "Description" fields have automatically been flagged as required:true; this was derived from annotations on the corresponding members of the bean - see the SupplyItemHB.java tab.

You can use DMI to add business logic that takes place before and after Hibernate operations to enforce security or add additional data validation rules.

Example.title: Beanless Mode
Example.description:
Beanless mode allows Hibernate to be used for persistence without writing any Java code at all. Declare the properties of the object in the DataSource descriptor (*.ds.xml file), and SmartClient will generate the Hibernate configuration automatically. The Admin Console can be used to generate the underlying SQL table as well, meaning, the only file that needs to be created is the *.ds.xml file.

As with the previous example, the grid below provides the ability to search, edit, and delete records.

Beanless mode helps to avoid writing boilerplate Java code (several classes full of getter and setter methods that do nothing) for simple entities. Even in beanless mode, DMI can still be used to add Java business logic that takes place before and after Hibernate operations. The Hibernate data is represented as a Java Map.

A mixture of beanless mode and normal Hibernate beans can also be used, even in the same transaction.

Example.title: HB Advanced Filtering
Example.description:
Use the FilterBuilder to construct queries of arbitrary complexity. The FilterBuilder, and the underlying AdvancedCriteria system, support building queries with subclauses nested to any depth. Add clauses to the query with the "+" icon and add nested subclauses with the "+()" button. Click "Filter" to see the result in the ListGrid.

Note that this example is backed by a "hibernate" DataSource. The SmartClient Server is automatically generating the Hibernate Criteria Queries (including database-specific SQL where necessary) to implement the filters that the FilterBuilder can assemble. This works adaptively and seamlessly with client-side Advanced Filtering. The generated Criteria query will yield exactly the same resultset as the client-side filtering. This means SmartClient is able to switch to client-side filtering when its cache is full, giving a more responsive, more scalable application.

Example.description:
This example shows a simple way to implement an update-able parent-child relationship with SmartClient, the SmartClient Server and Hibernate. Fom the various source tabs, it can be seen that "Order" and "OrderItem" are related via a unidirectional set collection in Hibernate. The order DataSource also declares its "items" field as being of type masterDetail_orderItemHB, which tells SmartClient to use that DataSource as the schema when processing the detail lines. With this configuration in place, creating a UI capable of updating across this parent-child association becomes extremely easy (only two lines of SmartClient code, beyond the creation and layout of the visual components themselves, is required).

Click a record in the top grid to see the order's details and the associated detail lines in the form and grid below. Edit the order information using this screen (both header and detail - double-click the grid to edit the details); when "Save" is clicked, SmartClient will submit the master and detail information together, and Hibernate will save all changes as a single operation.

Example.title: Data Selection
Example.description:
This example shows the SmartClient Server's support for flattening and reconstructing hierarchical data, by use of XPaths. The ListGrid below shows each user's address, city and state as if those fields were part of the user's data. In fact, this address information is held in a separate Address bean. This information is extracted from the separate bean at fetch time by the SmartClient Server, based purely on the XPath declarations of those fields in the DataSource.

More interestingly, the SmartClient Server is also able to reconstruct the hierarchical data from the flattened version, again transparently by use of the XPath. This means that you can update the flattened fields in this example - (e.g. Change a user's city and notice how the changes are correctly persisted).

Note also that the User bean has a password attribute which is being completely excluded from this example. When you specify dropExtraFields on a DataSource, as is done here, SmartClient Server returns just those fields defined in the DataSource. So, in this example, the existing schema can be used, whilst easily retaining tight control over what gets delivered to the client. This includes related entities as well as simple attributes.

Click a record in the grid to see the order's details in the form. Edit the user details and click "Save Changes". Using the declared XPaths, the SmartClient Server will populate any changed flattened field back into its correct place in the hierarchy, allowing the data provider (Hibernate, in this case) to persist the change.

Example.title: Spring with Beans
Example.description:
This example demonstrates how SmartClient can be used to call pre-existing Spring business logic, and provides a general sample of integrating with beans-based persistence systems. NOTE: if you want to use Hibernate in a new application, use the built-in HibernateDataSource connector, not this code. The sample code shown here has less features than the built-in connector (which supports advanced search, multi-level sort, automatic transactions, and other features).

In this example, Hibernate's Criteria object can be created from SmartClient's DSRequest in order to fulfill the "fetch" operation, with data paging enabled. Hibernate-managed beans can be populated with inbound, validated data with a single method call.

Example.title: Java Beans
Example.description: SmartClient DataSource operations can be fulfilled by returning Java Beans (aka EJBs or POJOs) from existing business logic. When the SmartClient DSResponse.setData() API is called, the Java objects are automatically translated to JavaScript, transmitted to the browser, and provided to the requesting component. See the sample implementation of the "fetch" operation in SupplyItemDMI.java.

Example.title: DMI
Example.description: Direct Method Invocation (DMI) allows mapping of DataSource operations directly to Java methods, via XML configuration in a DataSource descriptor (*.ds.xml file). The arguments of your Java methods are automatically populated from the inbound request. See the sample implementation in SupplyItemDMI.java.

Example.title: Auto Transactions
Example.description:
SmartClient Hibernate DataSources participate fully in automatic transaction management (Power and Enterprise Editions only).

Drag multiple records from the left-hand grid to the right. SmartClient will send the updates to the server in a single queue. SmartClient Server will automatically treat that queue as a single database transaction. This is the default behavior, and requires no code or configuration to enable it. However, if required, very flexible, fine-grained control over transactions is possible, through configuration, code or a combination of the two.

Example.title: HB Upload
Example.description:
This example uses a DynamicForm bound to a DataSource with a field of type imageFile to enable files to be uploaded and both a ListGrid and TileGrid to display the existing records, via a shared ResultSet.
