ExampleFolder.title: Transactions
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient provides robust support for transactional applications.

Queueing makes combining operations together into a single transaction extremely easy, for more efficient data loading and transactional saves.

Automatic Transaction Management support in the SmartClient Server, with specific implementations for the built-in SQL and Hibernate DataSources, allows for queued requests to be committed or rolled back as a single database transaction. This feature is only available in Power and Enterprise editions.

Transaction Chaining allows for declarative handling of data dependencies between operations submitted together in a queue. This feature is only available in Power and Enterprise editions.

Example.title: Simple Queueing
Example.description:
Queueing allows any set of DataSource operations to be combined into a single HTTP request, without requiring any special code to be written to transport the combined inputs and outputs.

Click the "Find Orders" button and the example will load both the selected user's details and all the orders associated with that user, as a single request. Queueing works transparently to the components involved, so for example, scrolling down in the orders grid causes data paging to be activated, exactly as though the grid had done a fetch that was not combined into a queue.

As queueing is transparent to components, a screen full of various components which need to load data from different sources can participate in a queue without any special component-specific code, and with no need to rework how data is transferred if new components are added. Each component can be treated as though it were standalone.

On the Server-side, queueing makes it simple to focus on secure, reusable data operations and other services, which can then be accessed in arbitrary combinations according to the data loading and saving requirements of particular screens, with no need to write brittle, screen-specific server code.

Queueing works even when the operations are on different data providers (as in this case, where the user details are coming from Hibernate and the order details are coming from the SmartClient Server SQL provider).

Example.title: Automatic Transaction Management
Example.description: Drag multiple records from the left-hand grid to the right. SmartClient will send the updates to the server in a single queue; SmartClient Server will automatically treat that queue as a single database transaction. This is the default behavior, and requires no code or configuration to enable it. However, if required, very flexible, fine-grained control over transactions is possible, through configuration, code, or a combination of the two.

Example.title: Master/Detail Add
Example.description:
This example makes use of the SmartClient server's support for setting DSRequest properties dynamically at runtime, based on responses to requests earlier in the same queue.

Edit the order header details, then add one or more lines. When "Save Order" is clicked, SmartClient will send multiple DataSource requests to the server. One to save the Order Header, and one each for every line that has been entered. However, they will combined into a single HTTP request, so that a transactional commit is possible. As this sample is backed by SmartClient SQLDataSources, the queue is automatically assembled into a single transaction (in Power Edition and above).

New orders are given an automatically generated sequence value as a primary key, which the "orderItems" use to establish a relationship with their order.

As a result of the values tag in the "queuedAdd_orderItem" DataSource definition, the server will set the "orderID" property on each order item to the unique sequence value assigned to the order header when it was saved.

This entire interaction is accomplished by simply re-using the capability of the DataSource to add new records, without the need to write any server-side code. SQL DataSources are shown, but this interaction works with any DataSource that can support CRUD operations, including custom DataSources and even a mix of DataSources that use different storage systems.

The values tag (and the similar property criteria tag) are specified using the Velocity Template Language, so the support is very flexible.

Example.title: Mass Update
Example.description:
Click on any cell to start editing, then Tab or Down Arrow past the last row in the grid to create a new row. Alternatively, click the "Edit New" button to create a new data-entry row at the end of the grid. When the "Save" button is clicked, all changes (changed rows and new orows) are sent to the server in a queue, as a single HTTP request.

Because all of the changes arrive on the server at once, committing them as a single transaction becomes possible. If the built-in SQL or Hibernate dataSources are being used, and the Power edition or above is used, automatic transactional commit is the default. Plus, because SmartClient's queueing support is completely unobtrusive and requires no extra code on either client or server, as soon there is an operation that can update a single record, then it automatically becomes an operation that can participate in SmartClient queued updates and automatic transactional commits.

Example.title: Multi-Row Drag & Save
Example.description:
Drag employee records into the Project Team Members list. SmartClient recognizes that the two DataSources are linked by a foreignKey relationship, and automatically uses that relationship to populate values in the records that are added when a drop occurs. SmartClient also populates fields based on current criteria and maps explicit title Fields as necessary.

Multi-row selection is enabled on the Employees grid, so select multiple employees can be selected and dragged to the Teams grid in one action. As the grids are databound, this drag and drop action will send data operations to the server automatically, using SmartClient queueing to ensure all the updates arrive on the server together and, as this example is backed by a SmartClient SQLDataSource, are committed together in a single database transaction (in Power Edition and above).

Example.title: Many-to-Many Drag & Save
Example.description:
Select a team. The ListGrid on the left will populate with employees not currently in the selected team while the ListGrid on the right will populate with the employees who are currently part of the selected team. Drag employees from the left to the right to add the selected employees to the team.

This sample uses a traditional pivot table design for the many-to-many relationship (many employees can be part of a team and an employee can be part of many teams).

Multi-record selection is enabled on the Employees grid, so multiple employees can be selected and dropped into a team in one action. Because these two grids are databound, SmartClient will automatically utilize queueing to ensure that all updates are performed on the server in a single transaction.

Example.title: Rollback
Example.description:
SmartClient Server detects when a DSRequest that is part of a transaction fails, and automatically rolls the complete transaction back.

Change several records in the grid, then click "Save". The underlying DataSource specifies a hasRelatedRecord validation on the country name, looking up against all the countries of the world. if country's name is changed to something non-existent, that validation will fail and the entire transaction will be rolled back. All of the changes will remain pending (the changed values will still be shown in blue), and if the page is refreshed note that the data is unchanged on the server.

Correct the validation error and click "Save" again, the transaction will be committed and the changes will be persisted.

Example.title: Transactional User Operations
Example.description:
User-written operations, in this example, hand-crafted JDBC updates, can be included in SmartClient automatic transactions, and will be committed or rolled back alongside the normal SmartClient operations.

Edit rows in the grid, then click "Good Save". The changes will be persisted to the database as part of a queue that also includes a user-written JDBC update to a "lastChanged" table; the DMI method has been written to use the SmartClient transaction (see the "JS" and "JDBCOperations.java" tabs). The example will then fetch the current value from the lastUpdated table and display it in the blue label. Note that it has been updated.

Now make further changes and click "Bad Save". This causes a deliberately broken version of the user-written JDBC update to be run, resulting in an SQL error and a rolled-back transaction (with an error dialog referring to an unknown column). Note that the changes have not been saved (they are still presented in blue, to show that they are pending) and the "lastUpdated" label has not changed. The entire transaction, both SmartClient requests and the user-written query, have all been rolled back. Now click "Good Save", and see how the pending changes are persisted and the "lastUpdated" label changes to reflect this.

ExampleFolder.title: Custom DataSources
ExampleFolder.description: Examples showing how to leverage the SmartClient Server to create partially or completely customized DataSource implementations.

Example.title: Javabean Wizard
Example.description: SmartClient's Visual Builder tool provides an extremely easy and completely codeless way to create DataSources based on your existing Javabeans and POJOs. Click the "New" button, select "JavaBean", and enter the name of an existing Javabean class. Visual Builder will create a DataSource descriptor that is almost complete - Simply connect it up to the custom DataSource implementation with the serverConstructor property and it's ready to go.

Example.title: Simple (Hardcoded)
Example.description:
This example shows an entirely custom DataSource. It is created by extending BasicDataSource and implementing the four core CRUD methods. In this case, a static List of Maps is maintained that are initialized with hard-coded data every time the server starts (although this code could actually do anything). This approach allows completely custom data operations to be simply plugged in to the SmartClient Server framework.

Note also that this code deals directly with Java Maps and Lists, without worrying about format conversions, even custom code leverages the SmartClient Server's automatic and transparent translation of request data, from JSON to Java and back to JSON.

Example.title: ORM DataSource
Example.description:
This example shows an entirely custom DataSource that connects SmartClient Server to Hibernate. It is a very simple implementation created by extending BasicDataSource and implementing the four core CRUD methods. In this case, a single DataSource implementation handles a single Hibernate entity. Features such as data pagination, server-side sorting and filtering are not implemented here.

Creating an equivalent adapter for Toplink or Ibatis or some other ORM solution would be a fairly simple matter of replacing the Hibernate-specific code in this example with the equivalent specifics from the other ORM system.

As with the other custom DataSource examples, note how the ORMDataSource.java code deals entirely in native Java objects - even entirely custom DataSources benefit from SmartClient Server's robust and comprehensive Javascript<->Java translation.

Example.title: Reusable ORM DataSource
Example.description:
This example shows an entirely custom DataSource that connects SmartClient Server to Hibernate (note that this is just an example of the principles involved - SmartClient Server's built-in Hibernate support is considerably more sophisticated than the simple adapter shown here). It is created by extending BasicDataSource and implementing the four core CRUD methods. In this case, the DataSource is connecting requests to Hibernate Criteria queries and the saveOrUpdate method.

This implementation, though simple, is fully functional and could be used unchanged in a real application. It supports all four CRUD operations, as well as data pagination, server-side sorting and filtering, client cache synchronization and is actually persisting the data to a real database. In this case, the single DataSource implementation handles two different entities using Reflection. Note that it is a simplified version of the built-in connector that handles AdvancedCriteria filtering.

As with other custom DataSource examples, note how the ORMDataSource.java code deals entirely in native Java objects. Even entirely custom DataSources benefit from SmartClient Server's robust and comprehensive Javascript<->Java translation.

Example.title: Editable Server-Side DataSource
Example.description:
This example demonstrates a DataSource whose definition is stored in a SQL database rather than in a static *.ds.xml file. The fields of the DataSource can be editted in the grid below. Pressing "Reload" shows a DynamicForm bound to the modified DataSource.

This pattern can be used to allow end users to dynamically change the definition of DataSources in an application. For example, add new fields, or add additional validators to existing fields.

ExampleFolder.title: Export
ExampleFolder.description: Exporting Data from DataSources and DataBoundComponents.

Example.title: Formatted Export (Declared Formats)
Example.description:
Exporting client-side data from a DataBoundComponent is possible with SmartClient using declared format strings that are auto-converted to Excel format at export time. This means that data is exported as seen in the component, including all of the effects of client-side formatters (except for custom formatters written in Javascript code) and hilites. Data exported this way appears in the spreadsheet with the same formatting seen in the client, but retains its underlying date, time or number value - this is usually the ideal scenario.

In the example below, choose an export format from the list, decide whether to download the results or view them in a window using the checkbox and click the "Export" button.

Data is exported according to the filters and sort order on the grid and includes the formatted values and field-titles as seen in the grid.

Example.title: Formatted Export (Custom Formatters)
Example.description:
Exporting client-side data from a DataBoundComponent is possible with SmartClient. This means the data as seen in the component, including all of the effects of all client-side formatters (including custom formatters) and hilites. Data exported this way appears in the spreadsheet as formatted text. In the particular case of dates, this behavior can be overridden for each export, because exporting formatted dates can be undesirable - if the value is exported as a formatted string, Excel is not able to recognize it as a date.

Custom formatting for dates is often not necessary, because declared FormatStrings are flexible enough to handle the majority of formatting requirements. The example below shows a (rather contrived) case where custom formatters really are required.

In the example, choose an export format from the list, decide whether to download the results or view them in a window using the checkbox and click the "Export" button.

Data is exported according to the filters and sort order on the grid and includes the formatted values and field-titles as seen in the grid. Depending on how you set the "export dates as formatted strings" checkbox, you will either see dates with some default format, or the actual strings shown in the ListGrid.

Example.title: Formatted Server-Side Export
Example.description:
Using format strings declared in your DataSource descriptor files, it is possible to export formatted values to spreadsheet packages like Excel purely server-side. Declaring formats in the DataSource descriptor also allows you to share formats between client-side and server-side code, so a single declaration pervasively affects how a field is formatted, both client-side and for exports. Data exported this way appears in the spreadsheet with the same formatting seen in the client (assuming you are sharing the format client-side), but retains its underlying date, time or number value - this is usually the ideal scenario.

In the example below, choose an export format from the list, decide whether to download the results or view them in a window using the checkbox and click the "Export" button.

Data is exported according to the filters and sort order on the grid and includes the formatted values and field-titles as seen in the grid.

Example.title: PDF Export
Example.description:
SmartClient provides comprehensive support for rendering UI into a print-friendly fashion, and exporting to PDF.

Click the "Print Preview" button and note the following things:

  • All components have simplified appearance (eg gradients omitted) to be legible in black and white
  • The ListGrid had a scrollbar because it wasn't big enough to show all records, but the printable view shows all data
  • Buttons and other interactive controls that are not meaningful in print view are omitted
Click the "Export" button to download a .pdf of the printed view.

Example.title: Custom Export
Example.description:
It is possible to produce a formatted export using DMI and affect the data server-side. This example shows a normal export via a DMI in an operationBinding, where the DMI enhances the exported data, formatting the "Independence" date field and adding a calculated field "gdppercapita" on the server-side.

Choose an Export format from the list, decide whether to download the results or view them in a window using the checkbox and click the "Export" button. In this case, exporting to all formats is achieved via operationBindings that specify the server DMI and, in the case of exports to JSON, with the exportAs flag. See the "JS" and "worldDSExportCustom" tabs below.

Example.title: Custom Export (Custom Response)
Example.description: Entirely custom data can be exported via a DMI. Click the button to issue a call to dataSource.exportData() with an operationId that specifies a server DMI. In this example, the DMI method ignores all the regular export parameters, calls doCustomResponse() and writes directly into the response output stream.

Example.title: Auditing
Example.description:
DataSources can automatically capture a log of changes by storing Records in a second DataSource, called an "audit DataSource".

Click in the grid below to edit supplyItem records. Underneath the separator labeled "Browse Audit Data" is a second grid that shows the audit data captured as changes are made to supplyItem records.

The audit DataSource is automatically created, and because it's a normal DataSource, you can simply bind a ListGrid to it to view the audit data, and the audit data is also searchable just like any DataSource.

Enabling this feature just requires setting audit="true" in the DataSource definition (.ds.xml file); the audit DataSource is created automatically, and for SQLDataSource, even the underlying SQL table is automatically created so no other settings are needed.

ExampleFolder.title: Upload / Download
ExampleFolder.description: Samples with Upload and Download files

Example.title: Upload
Example.description:
This example uses a DynamicForm bound to a DataSource with a field of type imageFile to enable files to be uploaded to both a ListGrid and a TileGrid, to display the existing records, via a shared ResultSet.

Enter a Title and select a local image-file to upload and click "Save" to upload the file. Note that the file-size is limited to 50k via the DataSourceField property maxFileSize (see the mediaLibrary tab below).

imageFile fields can either display a download/save icon-pair and title, or can render the image directly inline. Use the buttons below to switch between the TileGrid and ListGrid views to see each of these behaviors. Note that both components can render either UI for imageFile fields and will do so automatically, according to the value of field.showFileInline.

Example.title: Batch Data Upload
Example.description:
This example shows the BatchUploader in action. The BatchUploader encapsulates the end-to-end process of importing flat data into a DataSource, including transformation and validation of the import data, all without any client-side or server-side code required.

Follow the instructions in the example. Note that the download link is provided to give suitable example data to try with the BatchUploader - this would not normally be downloaded.

Example.title: MultiFileItem
Example.description:
This example shows the behavior of a multiple file upload widget.

When using this, implement cascading record deletion server-side, either with the SQL schema for the table, or with DMI.

Example.title: Custom Download
Example.description:
This sample shows a custom download in which server-side Java logic generates data to be downloaded to the user. This pattern can be used to download a file that is derived from DataSource data, such as exporting DataSource data in a custom text format, or via third-party libraries that can produce some kind of structured file (such as an .rtf or .pdf file).

Select multiple records in the grid below and press the "Download Descriptions" button. This will produce a simple text file with descriptions for all of the selected records.

Example.title: Custom Binary Field
Example.description:
Support for binary fields is built-in to the framework, including saving binary field values to SQL, Hibernate or JPA, for downloading later.

This example shows how to implement a binary field if a Custom DataSource were being built, that does not use the built-in support for binary field persistence.

UI controls with built-in support for binary fields will then show controls for uploading and downloading files, which will work with any custom DataSource.

ExampleFolder.title: Real-Time Messaging
ExampleFolder.description: RTM module provides low-latency, high data volume streaming capabilities for latency-sensitive applications such as trading desks and operations centers.

Example.title: Portfolio Grid
Example.description:
The grid below is receiving simulated, real-time updates of stock data via the Real Time Messaging (RTM) module. The RTM module provides low-latency, high data volume streaming capabilities for latency-sensitive applications such as trading desks and operations centers.

Randomly generated updates will stream from the server for 90 seconds. Click "Generate More Updates" to restart streaming.

The RTM module can connect to Java Message Service (JMS) channels without writing any code, or can be connected to custom messaging solutions with a simple adapter.

Example.title: Stock Chart
Example.description:
The chart below is receiving simulated, real-time updates to stock values via the Real Time Messaging (RTM) module. The RTM module provides low-latency, high data volume streaming capabilities for latency-sensitive applications such as trading desks and operations centers.

Randomly generated updates will stream from the server for 90 seconds. Click "Generate More Updates" to restart streaming.

Right click on the chart to switch the type of visualization.

ExampleFolder.title: Server Scripting
ExampleFolder.description: Simple business logic and validation rules can be embedded directly in *.ds.xml files. Use Java, or scripting languages such as Groovy or JavaScript.

Example.title: User-Specific Data
Example.description:
This example shows the use of some simple user-written server code in conjunction with SmartClient databound dragging features and the SmartClient SQL DataSource and Server Scripting, to implement a simple, but secure, shopping cart example.

Via Server-side Scripting, the "cartItem" DataSource declares that all DataSource operations should go through a custom server script DataSource.script before proceeding to read or write the database. DataSource.script adds the current sessionId to the DSRequest, so that the user can only read and write to their own shopping cart.

Drag items from the left-hand grid to the right-hand grid. Edit the quantity in the right-hand grid, or delete records. Verify that the example is protecting each user's data from others by running the example in two different browsers (eg one Firefox and one IE). This creates distinct sessions with separate carts.

Example.title: Validation
Example.description: Use the "Item Id" ComboBox to select an item, enter a very large quantity (999999) and press the "Submit Order" button. <P/> The resulting validation error is based upon a server-side condition specified in the validator using inline scripting. It checks a related DataSource (StockItem) to see if there is sufficient quantity in stock to fulfill the order.

Example.title: HTTP Proxy
Example.description:
The SmartClient Server includes an HTTP Proxy servlet which supports contacting REST and WSDL web services as though they were hosted by a local web server, avoiding the "same origin policy" restriction which normally prevents web applications from accessing remote services.

The proxy is used automatically whenever an attempt to contact a URL on another host is performed. No special code is needed. In this example, a DataSource is configured to download the Slashdot RSS feed, with no server-side code or proxy configuration required.

Configuration files allow for restricting proxying to specific services that should be accessible to users through your application.

ExampleFolder.title: Charting
ExampleFolder.description:
SmartClient supports advanced charting components that work in all supported browsers, including mobile browsers, without requiring plugins and without writing browser-specific code.

SmartClient charting components are data-aware, and allow end users to switch both the type of chart and the placement of data on the fly.

Example.title: Simple Chart
Example.description:
Charts can be created with inline Javascript data.

Use the "Chart Type" selector below to see same data rendered by multiple different chart types. Right-click on the chart to change the way data is visualized.

Example.title: Multi-Series Chart
Example.description:
Multi-series charts can be viewed with "stacked" data (to show totals) or "unstacked" to compare values from each series. The "Area" chart type defaults to using stacked data, while the "Line" chart type defaults to unstacked. Use the default setting, or explicitly specify whether to stack data.

Use the "Chart Type" selector to see the same data rendered by multiple different chart types. Right-click on the chart to change the way data is visualized.

Note that the right-click menu offers the ability to switch to proportional rendering whenever the chart is in "Stacked" mode.

Example.title: Grid Charting
Example.description:
Data loaded into a ListGrid can be charted with a single API call.

Use the "Chart Type" selector below to see the same data rendered by multiple different chart types. Right-click on the chart to change the way data is visualized.

Edit the data in the grid to have the chart regenerated automatically.

Example.title: Dynamic Data
Example.description:
Charts can be created directly from a DataSource without a ListGrid.

Use the "Time Period" menu to change the criteria passed to the DataSource.

Use the "Chart Type" selector below to see same data rendered by multiple different chart types. Right-click on the chart to change the way data is visualized.

Example.title: Dual Axis
Example.description: Dual axis charts can be used to create a single chart that shows two data sets with different units (for example: sales in dollars and total units shipped) and/or very different ranges (for example: gross revenue, profit).

Example.title: Multi-Series
Example.description: Multi-Axis charts can show multiple series of data. Here, a stacked column chart represents multi-series data denominated in percents, while multiple lines show a second multi-series data denominate in number of events

Example.title: 3+ Axes
Example.description: 3+ axis charts can be created to show 3 different types or ranges of data. Right click on "Events" or "Throughput" to bring up a context menu for swapping them.

Example.title: Mixed Plots
Example.description:
In some cases you want to show some data series as one shape and other data series as another shape but use the same axis. This is commonly used when one series is of a fundamentally different kind than the other series (for example, a projection or average) but still has the same scale.

This example demonstrates a technique for doing this based on Dual-Axis charts, where the second axis has been explicitly hidden, and data values that do not apply have been omitted from the dataset.

ExampleFolder.title: Zoom Charts
ExampleFolder.description:
These examples show charts that allow users to intuitively navigate very large datasets by providing the ability to zoom into parts of the data.

These charts intelligently choose which data labels to show based on whether the data set covers a date range, a numeric range, or is simply a large set of unrelated values.

Example.title: Stock Prices
Example.description:
This example shows historical pricing data for several well-known stocks. The miniature "zoom chart" (underneath the main chart) shows the complete dataset and the main chart shows a subset of this range in more detail.

Use the zoom chart to choose a visible range in the main chart, either by dragging the scrollbar or by dragging the range boundaries.

Note how the main chart will intelligently use different labels for the horizontal axis depending on how much data is shown - years, months or days may be labeled depending on how deeply you zoom.

Example.title: Measurement Data
Example.description:
This example shows about 800 samples points from a continuous varying numerical function (a Bode plot of a Chebyshev filter).

Use the zoom chart to focus in on small parts of the dataset and note that the line remains smooth due to the large number of samples. Horizontal gradations automatically adjust to the range of the dataset being shown.

This zoom mode can be used to show various kinds of measurement data where many samples are taken.

Example.title: City Populations
Example.description:
This example shows population change for 271 U.S. cities, sorted alphabetically.

When there are too many cities visible, the chart will label every Nth city depending on available space. This allows the end user to rapidly find the desired city since the cities are sorted alphabetically; it would also work with other sorting orders such as east to west or north to south.

Example.title: Histogram Chart
Example.description:
A histogram chart shows a number of segments for each facet value on the x-axis, one for each legend facet value. However, unlike a column chart, in which each facet only has a length, in a histogram each segment has both a start (value property) and end value (defined via a metric).

In the sample below, move the mouse across the various segments to see the data values shown in a hover, and note how the segments can overlap each other. The stacking order can be changed through use of an additional metric - you can see how this works by picking a different Z-Ordering in the form above the chart.

APIs are also provided so that charts can set their data fill and line color. In this chart, custom colors are applied via getDataColor(), using a map of the facetValueIds. In the form above the chart, you can also assign a separate border color, which is applied using the new getDataLineColor() API.

Example.title: Scrolling Chart
Example.description:
The chart below automatically expands horizontally to show content - this is enabled by the autoScrollData property. Automatic expansion can be driven either to fit per-facet-value bar thicknesses specified by defining a getMinClusterSize() method for the chart, or by the requirement that all labels fit on the horizontal axis without overlapping.

By toggling "Scroll to Fit" below, you can see that without it, the labels must be rotated to fit the chart data in a typically-sized browser window. By toggling dynamic bar thickness, you can see that sizing bars precisely to fit their labels enables a better use of space than driving expansion by average label width, which is the default.

Example.title: Custom Date Ticks
Example.description:
The chart below shows how you can control the gradations that appear on charts. Its vertical gradations will always appear as 2 times a power of ten, and its horizontal gradations will always appear as one of the gradation time intervals configured by the picklist. If you make the chart narrow, you can see that if you've configured the gradation times to exclude quarters of a year, then only whole years will be shown.

Tick marks can also be shown along the axes of a chart showing gradations. The chart below is configured to show a major tick mark at every quarter of a year, and a minor tick mark for shorter intervals - months in this case.

ExampleFolder.title: Scatter Plots
ExampleFolder.description: Scatter Plots, Bubble Charts and Color charts allow anywhere from 2 to 4 continuous data values to be shown in a single plot, by representing data values as X axis position, Y axis position, shape size and shape color.

Example.title: Scatter Plot
Example.description:
Scatter plots can show two axes of continuous numeric data. Multiple data sets can be plotted in different colors.

Connecting lines can optionally be shown for each data series. Use the "Show Lines" drop-down below to choose between no lines, straight lines or smooth lines.

Example.title: Bubble Chart
Example.description:
A Bubble Chart is a scatter plot where an additional data value is represented by the size of the shape drawn at the data point.

Bubble Charts can show multiple data series, optionally as different shapes. Use the "Use Multiple Shapes" checkbox below to switch between modes.

Example.title: Color Scale Chart
Example.description:
A Color Scale Chart is a scatter plot where an additional data value is represented by the color of each data point.

In this sample, the color scale feature has been combined with the bubble chart feature, so each point represents 4 distinct data values: X-axis placement, Y-axis placement, size of point and color of point.

Example.title: Curve Fitting
Example.description:
Scatter Charts support calculation of best-fit lines or curves, also known as "trend lines" for time series data. Shown below is a 3rd-degree polynomial regression curve.

Use the controls above the chart to switch between linear or polynomial regression and change the regression degree. Users can also enable or disable regression lines via the default context menu.

Example.title: Mean & Deviation
Example.description:
Charts can show the average value for the data set as well as the standard deviation (a measure of how far data points are from the average).

In the chart below, the bright green line shows the average, and the bright blue lines show one standard deviation above average and below average.

Use the "Regenerate Random Data" button to see a new random data set.

Example.title: Error Bars
Example.description: Charts can display error bars showing intervals of values around each data point.

Example.title: Drill Up/Down
Example.description:
Click on any swatch in the legend area of the chart below to focus in on data for just one Region.

Click the red "X" button next to the "Selected Region" text to return to viewing all Regions.

Click on any segment in the stacked columns to likewise focus in on data for just the region that the segment represents.

This simple Drill-down interface is created by responding to the valueClick and legendClick events - see the code for details.

Example.title: CubeGrid Charting
Example.description:
This example shows binding to a multi-dimensional dataset, where each cell value has a series of attributes, called "facets", that appear as headers labelling the cell value. Drag facets onto the grid to expand the cube model.
Right click on any cell and pick "Chart" to chart values by any two facets.

Example.title: Log Scaling
Example.description: Charts can use logarithmic scaling, which shows equal percentage changes as the same difference in height. This is useful for data that spans a very large range.

Example.title: Interactive Data Points
Example.description: The data points in a chart can be interactive. Hover over a data point to see additional information, and click to edit.

Example.title: Adding Elements
Example.description: This example show a column chart where the average value is computed and shown as a red line by drawing the line when chartBackgroundDrawn() fires

ExampleFolder.title: Export
ExampleFolder.description: Exporting Charts and other widgets based on DrawPane (such as Gauge) as images.

Example.title: Chart Image Export
Example.description:
FacetCharts and other widgets based on DrawPane (such as Gauge) can be exported to PNG and other image formats.

Click the "Download as Image" button to save an image of the chart. You can drag resize the chart or right-click it to change how it displays so that you can obtain multiple different images of the chart.

Click the "Get PNG Data URL" button to display a PNG snapshot of the chart in the blue bordered area to the right of the chart. In most browsers, right-clicking the PNG will then provide options to save it. Note that this particular feature of the example cannot be supported in Internet Explorer 7 and earlier.

Example.title: Chart PDF Export
Example.description:
Screens can be exported as PDF (Portable Document Format) files. This includes FacetCharts and other widgets based on DrawPane (such as Gauge).

Press the "View as PDF" button below to view the exported version of the grid and chart below in a new browser window. Press "Download as PDF" to save the generated PDF to disk.

Note that the grid is editable and the chart will react to changes in the grid, so you can view or download several different PDFs showing the grid and chart.

Example.title: Drawing Export
Example.description: Select an export format and then click the Save button. SmartClient will trigger the browser's save dialog allowing the DrawPane to be saved as an image in the specified format.

Example.title: Custom Hovers
Example.description:
This example shows a custom hover interaction built using the getNearestDrawnValue() API to identify which point is nearest the mouse cursor.

A bright blue marker is placed over the data point nearest the mouse. Clicking anywhere on the chart shows the information the chart provides about the nearest data point in a DetailViewer under the chart.

Note that FacetChart has two built-in hover behaviors - showValueOnHover and showDataPoints (which can show custom hovers). This example focuses on custom hovers.

ExampleFolder.title: Drag & Drop
ExampleFolder.description: Drag & drop services and built-in drag & drop interactions.

ExampleFolder.title: Data Binding
ExampleFolder.description: Databound components have built-in dragging behaviors that operate on persistent datasets.

ExampleFolder.title: Cross-Window Drag
ExampleFolder.description: HTML5 drag & drop support enabling drag & drop between browser windows.

Example.title: Snap-to-grid Dragging
Example.description: Drag the box around the grid. It will snap into alignment according to the values set in the radio buttons below. Snap-to-grid dragging can be enabled separately for moving and resizing. Toggle the checkboxes to see this working.

ExampleFolder.title: Control
ExampleFolder.description: Navigation and action controls.

ExampleFolder.title: Buttons
ExampleFolder.description: SmartClient buttons are visually appealing, easily skinned, and easy to use.

Example.title: Appearance
Example.description: Buttons come in three basic types: CSS buttons, single-image buttons, and multiple-image stretch buttons. All share a basic set of capabilities.

Example.title: States
Example.description:
Move the mouse over the buttons, and click and hold to see buttons in different states. Click "Disable All" to put all buttons in the disabled state.
Edit the CSS style definitions to change the appearance of various states.

Example.title: Icons
Example.description:
Click and hold on the "Save" button to see the icon change as the button goes down. Note that the binoculars icon does not change when the button goes down. Click "Disable Save" to see the icon change to reflect disabled state.
Button icons can be left or right oriented, and can optionally react to the state of the button.

Example.title: Auto Fit
Example.description: Buttons can automatically size to accommodate the title and icon, and resize automatically when the title is changed, notifying components around them they have changed size.

Example.title: Radio / Toggle Behavior
Example.description: Click on the buttons for Bold, Italic, and Underline and note that they stick in a down state. Click on the buttons for left, center and right justify and note that they are mutually exclusive.

Example.title: Adaptive Width
Example.description:
The Button class has built-in adaptive width support, enabled by setting the canAdaptWidth property to true. If the parent container will overflow, an adaptive-width Button will hide its title in an attempt to prevent the parent container from overflowing.

An adaptive-width Button is shown below. Drag the resize bar to simulate varying widths of the parent container and see how the Button reacts.

ExampleFolder.title: Menus
ExampleFolder.description: Dynamic, appealing menus that can bind directly to data.

Example.title: Appearance
Example.description: Click "File" to see a typical File menu with icons, submenus, checks, separators, disabled items, and keyboard shortcut hints. Note the bevelled edge and drop shadow.

Example.title: Dynamic Items
Example.description: Open the "File" menu to see the "New file in.." item initially disabled. Select a project and note that the menu item has become enabled, changed title and changed icon. Pick "Project Listing" to show and hide the project list, and note the item checks and unchecks itself.

Example.title: Submenus
Example.description: Click "File" and navigate over "Recent Documents" or "Export as..." to see submenus.

Example.title: Custom Columns
Example.description: Open the menu to see a standard column showing item titles, and an additional column showing an option to close menu items. Clicking in the second column will remove the item from the menu.

Example.title: Embedded Components
Example.description:
SmartClient allows placing arbitrary controls within a Menu.

Click the "Menu" button below to open a sample menu. Note how the common typical Cut/Copy/Paste menu items have been collapsed into a more compact row of buttons, and the "Add Bookmark" item gives you the ability to override the default title for a new bookmark without leaving the menu.

SmartClient makes this very straightforward with the concept of an "embedded component", allowed for any MenuItem.

Example.title: Tree Binding
Example.description: Click on "Department" or "Category" below to show hierarchical menus. The "Category" menu loads options dynamically from the "SupplyCategory" DataSource.

Example.title: Adaptive Menu
Example.description: The AdaptiveMenu component can either display menu items inline, or in a drop-down, or mix the two modes according to available space.

Example.title: ToolStrips
Example.description: Click the icons at left to see "radio"-style selection. Click the drop-down to see font options.

Example.title: ToolStrips (Vertical)
Example.description: Toolstrips can also be vertically aligned.

Example.title: RibbonBar
Example.description:
A RibbonBar is a customized ToolStrip which displays controls in separately titled RibbonGroups.

The RibbonBar controls the overall presence, placement and text-alignment of each group's title and these can be overridden for individual groups. Groups can have multiple rows of controls (group.numRows) and additional columns of rows are automatically added when that number is exceeded. Controls can also span multiple rows (control.rowSpan).

The example below demonstrates a RibbonBar using it's default RibbonGroup and IconButton/IconMenuButton classes to show various groups with different layouts. Groups with horizontal and vertical buttons can be seen, some of each showing their menuIcons. The "New" and "Undo" buttons also have their showMenuIconOver attribute set to false, which disables mouseOver styling on the menuIcon.

Example.title: Dialogs
Example.description: Click "Confirm", "Ask" or "Ask For Value" to show three of the pre-built, skinnable SmartClient Dialogs for common interactions.

Example.title: Login Dialog
Example.description: Click "Login" to show SmartClient's built-in user login dialog. Try entering both good and bad credentials - user "barney", password "rubble" is a valid user.

Example.title: Slider
Example.description: Move either Slider to update the other. You can change the value by clicking and dragging the thumb, clicking on the track, or using the keyboard (once you've focused on one of the sliders)

Example.title: ColorPicker
Example.description: Use the radio buttons to set which mode the ColorPicker initially appears in, and the window position policy. Click "Pick a Color" and select a color from either the simple or complex picker - the "Selected color" label changes to reflect your selection. The ColorPicker also supports selecting semi-transparent colors - this is more easily seen in a skin that shows a background image (eg BlackOps).

Example.title: Navigation Bar
Example.description: Demonstrates a NavigationBar and configuring the forward and back buttons.

ExampleFolder.title: Basics
ExampleFolder.description: Basic capabilities shared by all SmartClient visual components.

ExampleFolder.title: Components
ExampleFolder.description: Basic capabilities shared by all SmartClient visual components.

Example.title: Create
Example.description: Click the button to create new cube objects.

Example.title: Draw
Example.description: Click the button to draw another Label component. The first Label is configured to draw automatically.

Example.title: Show & Hide
Example.description: Click the buttons to show or hide the message.

Example.title: Move
Example.description: Click and hold the arrow to move the van. Click on the solid circle to return to the starting position.

Example.title: Resize
Example.description: Click the buttons to expand or collapse the text box.

Example.title: Layer
Example.description: Click the buttons to move the draggable box above or below the other boxes.

Example.title: Stack
Example.description: HStack and VStack containers manage the stacked positions of multiple member components.

Example.title: Layout
Example.description: HLayout and VLayout containers manage the stacked positions and sizes of multiple member components. Resize the browser window to reflow these layouts.

Example.title: Inline components
Example.description: SmartClient GUI components are assembled from the same standard HTML and CSS as plain old web pages. So SmartClient controls can be added above, below, inline, and inside existing web page elements.

ExampleFolder.title: HTML
ExampleFolder.description: Mixing SmartClient components with HTML pages, chunks, and elements.

Example.title: Back Button
Example.description: SmartClient supports browser history management. Click the browser's Back button to go to a previous example, and click forward to return to this example. Even navigate off the SmartClient site and navigate back. SmartClient's History module allows for picking which application events create history entries.

Example.title: HTMLFlow
Example.description: The HTMLFlow component displays a chunk of standard HTML in a free-form, flowable region.

Example.title: HTMLPane
Example.description: The HTMLPane component displays a chunk or page of standard HTML in a sizeable, scrollable pane.

Example.title: Label
Example.description: The Label component adds alignment, text wrapping, and icon support for small chunks of standard HTML.

Example.title: Editing HTML
Example.description: The RichTextEditor supports editing of HTML with a configurable set of styling controls.

Example.title: Img
Example.description: The Img component displays images in the standard web formats (png, gif, jpg) and other image formats supported by the web browser.

Example.title: Dynamic HTML (inline)
Example.description: Embed JavaScript expressions inside chunks of HTML to create simple dynamic elements.

Example.title: Dynamic HTML (set)
Example.description: Click the buttons to display different chunks of HTML.

Example.title: Load images
Example.description: Click the buttons to load different images.

Example.title: Load HTML chunks
Example.description: Click the buttons to load different chunks of HTML.

Example.title: Load HTML pages
Example.description: Click the buttons to display different websites.

ExampleFolder.title: Interaction
ExampleFolder.description:
Basic interactive component capabilities.

SmartClient components provide hundreds of hooks for event handlers, including all the standard mouse, keyboard, and communication events.

Example.title: Mouse events
Example.description: Mouse over the blue square to see the color respond to that position. Click and hold to see a fade. If a mousewheel is present, roll up and down to change size. SmartClient components support the standard mouse events in addition to custom events like mouseStillDown.

Example.title: Drag events
Example.description: Click and drag the pawn over "Show Drop Reticle" to see a simple custom drag and drop interaction.

Example.title: Hovers / Tooltips
Example.description: Hover over the button, the image, the "Interesting Facts" field of the grid and the "Severity" form label to see various hovers.

Example.title: Context menus
Example.description: Right click (or option-click on Macs) on the Yin Yang image to access a context menu. Click on the "Widget" button to access the identical menu.

Example.title: Focus & Tabbing
Example.description: Press the Tab key to cycle through the tab order starting from the blue piece. Then drag reorder either piece, click on the leftmost piece and use Tab to cycle through again. Tab order is automatically updated to reflect the visual order.

Example.title: Custom Tab Order
Example.description:
Click a button to give it keyboard focus and use Tab and Shift+Tab keys to move focus through the buttons. Now use the select item to modify the tabbing order.
SmartClient provides simple APIs to manage tab position of specific components while maintaining automatic tabIndex management for the application as a whole.

Example.title: Custom Component Tab Order
Example.description: Arbitrary HTML or third party widgets can be included in the page's tab order via APIs on the special TabIndexManager class. This sample demonstrates the inclusion of some native HTML <button> elements. These native elements are present in the page's tab order at the expected position, and are updated automatically when the structure of the page is changed via the "Switch Members" button.

Example.title: Cursors
Example.description: Mouse over the draggable labels for a 4-way move cursor. Move over drag resizeable edges to see resize cursors. Mouse over the "Save" button to see the hand cursor, which is not shown if the "Save" button is disabled.

Example.title: Keyboard events
Example.description: Click the "Move Me" label, then use the arrow keys to move it around. Hold down keys to see the component respond to key repetition. SmartClient unifies keyboard event handling across browsers.

Example.title: Modality
Example.description: Click on "Show Window" to show a modal window. Note that the "Touch This" button no longer shows rollovers or an interactive cursor, nothing outside the window can be clicked. Clicks outside the window cause the window to flash and tabbing remains in a closed loop, cycling through only the contents of the window.

ExampleFolder.title: Sounds
ExampleFolder.description: The SmartClient Sound class allows developers to easily load and play audio files, using the HTML5 <audio> element (supported in all modern browsers). Sounds can enhance an application's user experience and provide feedback during interactions.

Example.title: Audio Playback
Example.description: This sample uses the Sound class to load and play an audio sample. Click the control buttons to play, pause and reset the sample. Note how the progress-bar indicates the current playback position of the sample.

Example.title: Audio Notifications
Example.description:
The Sound class can add valuable user feedback to an interaction. This sample uses sound to notify a user whether their interaction was successful.

Leave the "Email" field empty and click the "Submit" button to perform an invalid submission. The sample will play an error sound and show a dialog indicating what went wrong. Dismiss the error and populate both fields before submitting to get a successful submission notification.

Example.title: Printing
Example.description:
SmartClient provides comprehensive support for rendering UI into a print-friendly fashion, and exporting to PDF.

Click the "Print Preview" button and note the following things:

  • All components have simplified appearance (eg gradients omitted) to be legible in black and white
  • The ListGrid had a scrollbar because it wasn't big enough to show all records, but the printable view shows all data
  • Buttons and other interactive controls that are not meaningful in print view are omitted
Click the "Export" button to download a .pdf of the printed view.

Effects for creating a polished, branded, appealing application.

SmartClient supports rich skinning and styling capabilities, drag and drop interactions, and built-in animations.

Example.title: Drag list (move)

Example.title: Tree Reparent
Example.description: Dragging employees between managers in this tree automatically saves the new relationship to a DataSource, without writing any code. Make changes, then reload the page. The changes persist.

Example.title: Recategorize (Tree)
Example.description: Dragging items from the list and dropping them on categories in the tree automatically re-categorizes the item, without any code needed. Make changes, then reload the page. The changes persist. This behavior is (optionally) automatic where SmartClient can establish a relationship, via foreign key, between the DataSources two components that are bound to it.

Example.title: Recategorize (List)
Example.description: The two lists are showing items in different categories. Drag items from one list to another to automatically recategorize the items without writing any code. Make changes, then reload the page. The changes persist.

Example.title: Recategorize (Tile)
Example.description: Drag and drop animals between the grids in either direction, and the status of the dropped tile will change to match the filtered status of the TileGrid in which it was dropped. Select different values in the drop down lists above each TileGrid to change the animals that will appear in each grid.

Example.title: Copy
Example.description:
Drag employee records into the Project Team Members list. SmartClient recognizes that the two DataSources are linked by a foreign key relationship, and automatically uses that relationship to populate values in the record that is added when the drop occurs. SmartClient also populates fields based on current criteria and maps explicit title Fields as necessary.

In this example, note that SmartClient is automatically populating all three of the fields in the teamMembers DataSource, even though none of those fields are present in the employees DataSource being dragged from. Change the "Team for Project" select box, then try dragging employees across. Note that the Project Code column is being correctly populated for the dropped records.

Example.title: Persistent Reorder (Grid)
Example.description:
Click on a record to select it, or use Ctrl-Click on several records to select multiple records. Click on one of the selected records and drag the selection to a new position within the ListGrid. Release the mouse once the selection is in the desired position to drop the selected records.

On the ISC Developer Console, RPC tab, check the "Track RPCs" checkbox to be able to monitor DSRequests. Notice that there is only one request sent per drag & drop operation.

Example.title: Persistent Reorder (Tree)
Example.description:
Click on a node to select it, or, use Ctrl-Click on several nodes to select multiple nodes. Click on one of the selected nodes and drag the selection to a new position among their siblings. Release the mouse once the selection is in the desired position to drop the selected nodes.

On the ISC Developer Console, RPC tab, check the "Track RPCs" checkbox to be able to monitor DSRequests. Notice that there is only one request sent per drag & drop operation.

Example.title: Records across Windows
Example.description:
This sample demonstrates dragging data between two different browser windows.

Open a second browser window (or browser tab) with this same sample running. Drag records from the grid and drop them on the grid shown in the other browser.

Depending on your browser and operating system, it may be necessary to hover over the second browser tab or over an application icon to cause the tab or browser to come to the front so you can drop on it.

Data is transferred directly from one browser instance to another using HTML5 techniques. This allows you to build applications that span multiple browser windows or tabs, and makes it easier to take advantage of multiple physical screens.

ExampleFolder.title: Dashboards & Tools
ExampleFolder.description:
The Dashboards & Tools framework provides a set of components for building customizable user interfaces and tools. Examples include portals that can persist layout, report builders that allow end users to arrange data into a sharable "dashboard", diagramming or flow charting tools, and tools for UI creation such as form designers.

The components in the Dashboards & Tools framework are the foundation on which Visual Builder was created, and many of the features of Visual Builder can achieved by simply creating and configuring components in the Dashboards & Tools framework.

ExampleFolder.title: Palettes
ExampleFolder.description: Palettes organize and present the components available for the user to select and customize. Users choose items from palettes by clicking and/or dragging (depending on the palette type).

Example.title: Tree Palette
Example.description: Tree Palettes organize available components in a tree structure. The user can double-click or drag to create a component. Components can be copied and pasted using keyboard shortcuts Ctrl-C/V (or Cmd-C/V on Mac). To see this in action, create a component and confirm it is selected by clicking on it. Then press copy key, move the source component somewhere else and finally press the paste key.

Example.title: List Palette
Example.description: List Palettes organize available components in a list grid structure. The user can double-click or drag to create a component. Components can be copied and pasted using keyboard shortcuts Ctrl-C/V (or Cmd-C/V on Mac). To see this in action, create a component and confirm it is selected by clicking on it. Then press copy key, move the source component somewhere else and finally press the paste key.

Example.title: Tile Palette
Example.description: Tile Palettes organize available components in a tile grid structure. The user can double-click or drag to create a component.

Example.title: Menu Palette
Example.description: Menu Palettes present available components as a menu. The user can click or drag to create a component.

ExampleFolder.title: Edit Mode
ExampleFolder.description:
Edit Mode uses Edit Contexts manage a set of components that have persistent state. Edit Contexts automatically understand drag and drop from Palettes as a means of adding a persistent component; persistent components can also be added programmatically.

Edit Contexts separate persistent state from transient or incidental state so that only intentional changes by the user result in changes to persistent data.

Example.title: Collage Editor
Example.description:
This examples presents a simple collage editor based on a target canvas and an EditContext. Photos from a Tile Palette can be dropped into the collage. These photos can then be resized and dragged into the desired location to create a collage. Multiple photos can be selected by dragging a rectangle around the desired photos allowing them to be moved together.

A snap-to grid is also defined to limit the default placement and resize options. The grid is 20x20 pixels and is only shown when an active drag or resize takes place. To temporarily disable the snap-to feature hold down the shift key while dragging.

The resulting Component XML can be viewed at any time. Clicking on the "Destroy and Recreate" button will recreate the collage from saved state.

Example.title: Portal Layout
Example.description:
With the Tools framework you can create Palettes from which to drag Portlets. Try dragging from the TreePalette to the PortalLayout. Portlets will be created on the fly.

The PortalLayout in this example is embedded in an EditPane, so that the state of the PortalLayout (and its Portlets) can be persisted. Here the state is saved to a JavaScript variable, but other persistence mechanisms may be used. Click the "Destroy and Recreate" button to save the PortalLayout's state, destroy it, and then recreate it. The sequence is animated to illustrate the process.

Once you've created some Canvas portlets, try right-clicking on them to change their background color. Notice how code in the example updates the PortalLayout's edited state, so that the colors persist when you "Destroy and Recreate".

Example.title: Grid Portlets
Example.description:
In Edit Mode, Grid components can automatically save changes to criteria, fields, hiliting rules and other end-user settings.

Drag DataSource names from the palette on the left to the portal on the right. Portlets containing grids will be created on the fly. Change the criteria, field order or size, sort order, highlights, or grouping, then press "Destroy and Recreate" to see the grids re-created in the same layout and with the same settings.

In this sample, the state of the portal and grids is held temporarily in a variable; the state of the portal and grids can also be serialized to JSON or XML, and stored as a DataSource field value.

Example.title: Form Builder
Example.description:
With the Tools framework it is easy to create a simple form editor. This example uses a palette of pre-configured form items that can be dropped into the target DynamicForm to assemble the desired fields.

The field title can be edited by double-clicking on the field or title. The value entered into a field is saved in the FormItem's defaultValue property. The defaultValue for a BlurbItem is edited like a title. ValueMap values can be entered by right-clicking on the field and selecting Edit Options.

An EditContext is used to save and restore configured form and FormItems.

Example.title: Diagramming
Example.description:
With the Tools framework it is easy to create a simple drawing editor. This example uses a palette of pre-configured DrawItems that can be dropped into the target DrawPane. Position, size, and styling properties of the DrawItems are automatically persisted.

This sample persists into a JavaScript variable. Double-click or drag some Draw Items into the Draw Pane, then click the "Destroy and Recreate" button to save the state, destroy the DrawItems, and then recreate them.

Example.title: Mockup Editor
Example.description:
Most UI widgets have built-in editing behaviors that allow them to be configured by just typing in a simple string of text.

A simple Mockup Editor can be created by just enabling these behaviors plus drag and drop positioning.

This sample also shows snap-to-grid dragging. Hold down shift before starting a drag to turn off snap-to-grid. Arrow keys can also be used to move the selected component.

ExampleFolder.title: Persistence
ExampleFolder.description:
There are several persistence strategies to persist and recreate Edit Contexts.

  • Use a variable to store state, and recreate or duplicate an Edit Context from that variable.
  • Persist state to a DataSource.
  • Use Offline storage to persist state.

Example.title: Automatic
Example.description:
The state of an Edit Context can be saved to a variable. That variable can then be used to duplicate or recreate the Edit Context.

Try dragging some components from the Tile Palette to the Edit Pane. Click the "Destroy and Recreate" button to save the Edit Pane's state, destroy it, and then recreate it. The process is animated, to illustrate the process (which would otherwise occur instantly).

Example.title: DataSource
Example.description: The state of an Edit Context can be connected to a DataSource. Try dragging some components from the Tile Palette to the Edit Pane. Click on "Save" to save the state of the Edit Pane to a DataSource. Make some changes to the Edit Pane, and then click "Restore". Note how the state of the Edit Pane is restored to its saved state.

Example.title: Offline
Example.description:
The state of an Edit Context can be connected to Offline storage. Try dragging some components from the Tile Palette to the Edit Pane. Click on "Save" to save the state of the Edit Pane to a DataSource. Make some changes to the Edit Pane, and then click "Restore". Note how the state of the Edit Pane is restored to its saved state.

Try reloading the page to see saved state automatically restored. (Note that the example does not automatically save state).

Example.title: Portal Dashboard
Example.description:
With the Tools framework, you can create dashboards of portlets. This example uses a list of pre-configured grid portlets that can be viewed or edited.

Double-click a pre-configured dashboard to view the saved portal layout consisting of one or more grids. To make changes, select the dashboard and click Edit button. Change the criteria, field order or size, sort order, highlights, or grouping to see how these properties are persisted.

Select a dashboard and click Clone button to generate another copy for experimentation. Rename the new dashboard by right-clicking on the record and choosing Rename option.

ExampleFolder.title: Applications
ExampleFolder.description: Demos of complete applications based on SmartClient.

Example.title: Interactive Analytics
Example.description:
This example shows binding to a multi-dimensional dataset, where each cell value has a series of attributes, called "facets", that appear as headers labelling data values. Facets can be added to the view, exposing more detail, by dragging the menu buttons onto the grid, or into the "Row Facets" and "Column Facets" listings.

Facets can be removed from the view by using the menus to set a facet to a fixed value. For example, use the "Time" menu to show just data from 2002: "Time -> Fix Time Value -> All Years -> 2002".

Click the turndown controls on facet values to expand tree facets. Note that data loads as it is revealed by expanding and collapsing tree facets, by adding facets, or by scrolling in either direction. This allows users to navigate extremely large data sets.

Right click on any data value or facet value to generate a chart showing how that particular value varies along up to two facets. For example, click on any data value for "Office Paper Products" and choose "Chart -> Sales by Time and Region" to see how this category of products is selling in different regions and time periods. Switch to different chart types (eg Radar) on the fly. (Note: Chart support requires the Drawing Module. If not installed, the Analytics Module, including the CubeGrid and the remainder of this sample, will continue to function normally.)

Because the CubeGrid uses a DataSource to load data, it can be connected to any kind of server or data provider. This sample loads data from an SQL database.

You can get a WYSIWYG export to Excel after rearranging the cube by clicking the "Export" button.

The month chooser of the date picker, the operator chooser of the custom filter, and the header context menus of the ListGrid. SmartClient supports localization via configurable property files. See the documentation under "Internationalization and Localization" for more information about using existing locale files or creating custom locales.

The "unitCost" field is of type "currency" which is explicitly defined in the source as a SimpleType inheriting from float. Both the (editable) ListGrid and the DynamicForm respect the settings defined in this type definition.

Example.title: Customize Fields
Example.description: Edit field definitions in the grid below to override how this form binds to the "supplyItem" DataSource. This is a simplified example of how an application can be delivered that can be customized with organization-specific fields and rules. Dynamic schema binding makes building WYSIWYG editing interfaces very simple.
